She has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with her mother dying of a myocardial infarction at the age of 68 and her father suffering from hypertension and a stroke in his 60s as well. She has 2 adult daughters  both living out of state. She reports no known drug allergies.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Alberto Fernandez  a 68-year-old Hispanic male presents to the clinic with progressive shortness of breath and increasing lower extremity edema over the past two months. He also reports experiencing episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Increasing fatigue has limited his ability to engage in his usual daily activities.   He is a resident of San Diego  California  is married  and retired from his job as a school teacher three years ago. His wife reports noticing that he has been more forgetful recently and occasionally appears confused. Apart from a 40-pack year smoking history  he denies alcohol or substance abuse. He quit smoking 10 years ago. His diet is moderately balanced  and he doesn't engage in physical activity due to increasing fatigue  shortness of breath followed by physical exertion.  His medical history reveals a myocardial infarction seven years ago  for which he underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. Mr. Fernandez has also been treated for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. There is a history of Type-2 diabetes mellitus controlled with oral hypoglycemics. There is no known history of asthma  COPD  or other pulmonary or kidney diseases.   Family history is significant for his father  who died of a stroke at the age of 79  and his mother  who suffered from chronic hypertension and passed away at the age of 84. His older sister is currently living with congestive heart failure.  Mr. Fernandez's medications include Aspirin 81 mg daily  Lisinopril 10 mg daily  Metformin 500 mg twice daily  and Simvastatin 20 mg at bedtime. He claims to adhere consistently to his medications. He is allergic to Penicillins which have caused a rash and pruritus.   Upon physical examination  Mr. Fernandez is found to have bilateral basal rales in lung auscultation  an S3 gallop  distended jugular veins  and pitting edema (grade 2+) in the lower extremities. His blood pressure is 140/90  pulse rate 76  and respiratory rate 22. Labs are pending.  From the presentation  labs  and history  symptoms seem consistent with congestive heart failure. Mr. Fernandez will require more detailed investigations like chest X-ray  ECG  and echocardiography. He is advised to limit salt and fluid intake and to monitor his weight regularly. Dietary and lifestyle modifications may also be beneficial. Further management strategy is to be decided based on these findings. An assessment of his cognitive function is also importantly needed due to his recent forgetfulness.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Juan Alvarez is a 63-year-old Hispanic male who presents to the clinic today with complaints of progressive shortness of breath  fatigue and swollen ankles. His shortness of breath has worsened over the past two weeks  now affecting him even during minor exertions and often waking him up at night. His wife also noticed that he has been increasingly fatigued  spending most of the day sitting or lying down. Over the past week  he noted that his ankles are swollen  causing difficulty putting on shoes and socks. He denies any chest pain  palpitations  or syncope.   Mr. Alvarez is a retired construction worker. He is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally  drinks about 2 to 3 beers per week. He has been married for 35 years and has 3 adult children.   He has a past medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which was diagnosed 15 years ago and is managed with Metformin. He also has Hypertension for the past 10 years and takes Lisinopril. He does not recall ever having a heart condition before. His father developed heart failure in his 70's.   He is currently overweight with a BMI of 28.2. He has not checked his blood pressure at home recently  but his last check-up a year ago showed a blood pressure of 140/85 mm Hg. His A1C at that time was 7.9%.  Overall  this patient’s demographics  past medical history  and presentation are consistent with characteristics seen commonly in heart failure patients. The progressive shortness of breath  fatigue  and ankle swelling are classic symptoms of heart failure. His Hispanic ethnicity  male gender  and age also align with the typical demographic representation of heart failure in literature. Additionally  the presence of uncontrolled Hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes  and being overweight predisposes him to the development of heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of progressive shortness of breath  chronic fatigue  and swollen ankles and feet. He mentions that his symptoms have worsened over the last week; he has difficulty with common tasks such as walking to the mailbox or getting dressed and needs to sleep with multiple pillows to breathe comfortably at night.   Mr. Doe has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which were diagnosed about 8 years ago. He admits that the management of these conditions has been inconsistent due to medication cost and lack of regular primary care follow-ups. He has a 45-pack-year smoking history  although he quit smoking 5 years ago. He also reports occasional alcohol consumption.  Family history is significant for heart disease; his father died of a heart attack at the age of 58. He is currently retired and lives alone. He denies drug use and has no known drug allergies. His current medications include Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension.  On examination  he appears fatigued and tachypneic. His blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg and pulse is 110 bpm. Auscultation of the heart reveals an S3 gallop. Lung exam reveals slight rales at the lung bases. Abdominal examination is unremarkable  but there is visible edema in the lower extremities  extending up to the shins.  The clinical presentation and examination findings are strongly indicative of heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Sanchez  a 65-year-old Hispanic female  presents to the clinic complaining of progressive fatigue and swelling in her lower extremities over the past three weeks. She also reports feeling short of breath with even minor exertion such as walking from the bedroom to the kitchen. She has been waking up at night gasping for breath  feeling like she is drowning. She also mentions a recent weight gain of about 10 pounds in the past month.  Her past medical history is notable for:  1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus controlled with Metformin 2. Essential Hypertension managed with Lisinopril 3. Early Stage Chronic Kidney Disease 4. She had a myocardial infarction 7 years ago.  Ms. Sanchez is widowed and lives alone. She denies any use of tobacco  alcohol  or illicit substances. Her medication adherence has generally been good. She is currently not on any heart failure specific drugs.  On physical examination  she appears tired and has dry  cool skin. Her heart rate is 90 beats per minute  blood pressure 145/90 mmHg  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  with an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Auscultation of the heart shows an S3 gallop and mitral regurgitation murmur. Lung auscultation reveals basal crackles bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows hepatomegaly. Lower limb examination reveals pitting edema up to the level of the knees.  This presentation is suggestive of congestive heart failure (CHF)  given Ms. Sanchez's significant cardiovascular history and the symptoms she is presenting with. As a Hispanic woman over 60 with Type 2 Diabetes  Hypertension  and previous myocardial infarction  Ms. Sanchez fits into the demographic most affected by CHF as shown in the literature.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Samuel Harris is a 67-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath  palpitations  and constant fatigue for the past week. He also mentions a recent  rapid weight gain of about 12 pounds and increased swelling in his legs.  He has a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and a myocardial infarction 6 years ago. His hypertension and diabetes are generally well-controlled on medications. However  he confesses to missing his medication doses quite often over the past month due to forgetfulness. He also has a documented 40-pack year smoking history  but he quit smoking after his heart event 6 years ago. He denies any alcohol or recreational drug use.   Family history is notable for a father who died of a stroke at age 72 and a mother who had heart failure and passed away at 80.  Based on his age  medical history  and symptoms  there's a high suspicion for heart failure. His significant cardiac history and currently uncontrolled cardiovascular risk factors including hypertension and diabetes make him vulnerable to heart failure  which can be further supported by diagnostic tests and imaging.

Patient Presentation: Meet Mr. John  a 68-year-old African American male from a low-income urban community  who presents to the emergency department with symptoms of heart failure. He is an active smoker for the past 40 years and reports an average alcohol consumption. He is also suffering from obesity with a BMI of 32 and has moderate physical activity levels.  Chief Complaint: John complains of progressive shortness of breath on exertion and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea for the past two weeks. He also reports frequent dry coughs and fatigue  which are affecting his daily activities.  Past Medical History: John has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the last 10 years  for which he's taking oral medications as prescribed. He had an episode of acute myocardial infarction (MI) five years ago  which was successfully managed with angioplasty. There was no family history of any early cardiac disease. There are no known allergies.  Clinical Findings: On examination  John's blood pressure reads 145/95 mmHg and pulse shows 90 bpm. Crackles are heard bilaterally on chest auscultation  suggestive of pulmonary congestion. Jugular venous distension is noted  and lower extremity pitting edema is present  indicating fluid retention. There is also evidence of hepatomegaly. His BMI by measurements denotes obesity.  This patient's presentation  history  and physical examination findings are suggestive of chronic heart failure  likely due to an underlying combination of ischemic heart disease  hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and lifestyle factors. The patient requires further investigations including blood tests  chest X-ray and an echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis and to assess the severity of the heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Anderson is a 76-year-old African American male who presented at the emergency department complaining of increasing shortness of breath  worsening fatigue  and palpitations over the last three days. He particularly notices his dyspnea when trying to lie flat to sleep and has taken to sleeping upright in a chair for relief.   His medical history includes diagnosed hypertension for the past 15 years  type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years  and a myocardial infarction 5 years ago  for which he underwent angioplasty. He is an ex-smoker  quit around 7 years ago. He mentions he does not exercise due to fatigue and chest discomfort and has a poor diet with high salt and fat  mainly due to a lack of understanding about diet and health.   He has been prescribed and is adherent to Metformin for his diabetes  Lisinopril and Metoprolol for his hypertension  and Aspirin and Simvastatin for secondary prevention of heart disease. He has not had any previous surgeries.   His father died at the age of 79 from heart failure and diabetes  and his mother lived to her 80s but had hypertension and Alzheimer's Disease. He has three siblings  two brothers and a sister. One brother had a stroke in his 60s.   On examination  he is overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 30 kg/m2. He appears visibly distressed due to dyspnea. His heart rate is 96 bpm  respiratory rate is 24 breaths/min  blood pressure is 146/90 mmHg  and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. His lung fields have widespread coarse crackles  an indication of pulmonary congestion. His heart sounds reveal a third heart sound (S3 Gallop). There is evidence of peripheral edema in the lower limbs  as well as an raised Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP).  Mr. Anderson's clinical evaluation and prior medical history strongly suggest heart failure. Further cardiac imaging and laboratory testing will be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and formulate a comprehensive treatment plan.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Martinez  a 73-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic with chief concerns of increasing shortness of breath over the past few weeks  unexplained swelling of his lower extremities  increased fatigue  nocturnal cough and weight gain of approximately 10 pounds over one month. He reports orthopnea  having to prop up on three pillows to relieve his breathlessness at night. Mr. Martinez also mentions that lately   he is unable to walk his regular two blocks without stopping due to tiredness and occasional light-headedness.  Demographics:  He is a teetotaler  ex-smoker with a 30-pack year history and quit smoking 7 years ago. He lives alone  in a suburban community in Texas  is a retired school principal  widower for last 5 years  has 3 kids who live out of town  and is primarily English speaking. His support system is sufficient  with regular visits from his kids and neighbors assisting him with day to day activities.  Past Medical History:  He has a significant past medical history of type II Diabetes Mellitus for which he has been on Metformin for the last 10 years  Hypertension since 18 years  and was diagnosed with Dilated Cardiomyopathy three years earlier. He had also suffered an anterior wall Myocardial Infarction five years back  for which he underwent Percutaneous Coronary Intervention. He has been under medication for these conditions  but has been irregular due to forgetfulness since a year post his wife's death. He also admits to a poor diet and lack of regular exercise.  Family History:  There is a family history of Coronary Artery Disease  with his father having succumbed to a heart attack in his mid-sixties and an elder brother diagnosed with unstable angina currently under treatment.   Present Medication:  He is on metformin 500 mg BID  Lisinopril 10 mg OD  Atenolol 50 mg OD and Aspirin 75 mg once daily  besides occasional usage of Nitroglycerin sublingual tablets for angina relief.  Social History:  Mr. Martinez has no history of illicit drug use. He quit alcohol 25 years ago and quit smoking 7 years ago. He mentions that he is mostly sedentary as he watches television most of the day  and rarely involved in physical activity. He has a BMI of 30  thus being categorized as obese.   Review of Systems:  ROS is positive for an increasing difficulty in doing everyday tasks without feeling fatigued or breathless. He reports of gaining more weight recently and increased frequency of urination.  By integrating the data  the symptoms and signs presented by Mr. Martinez mark a profound concern towards an acutely decompensating chronic heart failure. Further investigation is proposed and a careful review and optimization of his daily medication regimen is imperative to prevent further exacerbation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Garcia  a 76-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic with complaints of increasing shortness of breath  persistent cough that produces white phlegm  rapid weight gain  swelling in the legs  ankles and feet  fatigue  irregular heartbeats and decrease in exercise tolerance over the past few weeks.  Mr. Garcia is a retired construction worker from El Paso  Texas. He lives with his wife. He is a former smoker with a 35-year pack history and quit about 15 years ago. Mr. Garcia's alcohol history consists of occasional beer on weekends. He has no known drug allergies.  His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years  hypertension for the past 15 years  and he had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago with subsequent angioplasty and stenting. Mr. Garcia's surgical history includes only an appendectomy at early 20s. His family history is significant for heart disease in both his father and older brother.  The medications he is currently on include Metformin 500mg twice a day for diabetes  Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension  and aspirin 81mg daily for heart disease prophylaxis.  He reports increasing difficulty to carry out light housework and has started to sleep on three pillows at night to help with the breathlessness. He believes his symptoms get worse when lying flat and afte eating meals.  Given Mr. Garcia's history of myocardial infarction and risk factors such as age  diabetes  and hypertension  he is at a high risk for heart failure. His current symptoms are strongly suggestive of heart failure and warrant further evaluation.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old African-American male presents to the clinic with increasing shortness of breath  fatigue  and swelling in his legs. The symptoms have been progressively worsening over the last two weeks. Patient also reports weight gain of approximately 5 pounds during this timeframe.  The individual has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 45-pack year smoking history. He had a myocardial infarction (MI) 10 years ago and underwent a coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery at that time. His family history is significant for heart disease  with his father dying from a MI at the age of 68. Currently  he lives alone  is partially dependent on his neighbors for his chores and meals  and says he is occasionally non-compliant with his prescribed medication regimen.  While he abstains from alcohol  he has not quit smoking despite repeated education and advice. His current medications include metformin  lisinopril  metoprolol  and aspirin. His blood pressure today is 145/90 mmHg  heart rate is 98 bpm  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Upon physical examination  elevated jugular venous pressure  pulmonary rales  and lower extremity pitting edema are noted. EKG shows left ventricular hypertrophy with prior anterior Q waves.  The above mentioned is a typical presentation of a patient with heart failure. African American males are disproportionately affected by heart failure  often at a younger age  and are more likely to have comorbid conditions such as hypertension and diabetes  both of which are risk factors for heart failure. The history of smoking and non-compliance with medications further increase his risk for exacerbations of heart failure. His current report of symptoms like shortness of breath  fatigue  swelling of legs and weight gain  along with physical examination findings align well with worsening congestive heart failure.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Williams  a 65-year-old African American male  retired truck driver  presents to the Emergency Department with increasing shortness of breath  worsening fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance for the past month. His symptoms have significantly worsened over the past week  rendering him breathless even at rest. He also reports a 10 lb unintentional weight gain in the last 2 weeks  bilateral leg swelling  and his wife has noticed he has been snoring loudly and irregularly at night. He denies any chest pain or pressure  nausea/vomiting  or dialed in cold sweat.   Past medical history is significant for high blood pressure diagnosed ten years ago  which has been poorly controlled despite amlodipine/benazepril 5/20 mg. He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin for the past 5 years. There is no history of smoking or alcohol abuse. He has been non-compliant with his prescribed diet and exercise routine recommended for his hypertension and diabetes.   Family history is significant for multiple first degree relatives with cardiovascular disease. His father died of a myocardial infarction at age 68  and his older brother had a heart bypass surgery at age 60.

Patient Presentation:  A 73-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with acute severe dyspnea  orthopnea  and swelling of both lower extremities. He reports that his symptoms have been progressively worsening over the course of two weeks. He also admits the symptoms become worse when he's lying flat and seem to alleviate somewhat when he's sitting upright. He rates his shortness of breath as 7/10 and is obviously in distress  sitting up in the bed  and using accessory muscles to breathe.  Past medical history (PMH) includes hypertension (HTN) for which he takes Lisinopril  diabetes mellitus type 2 (DMT2) managed with Metformin  and no known heart diseases. He has a longstanding smoking history of 35-pack years but quit 5 years ago.  No known drug allergies; family history is significant for heart disease with the patient's father having experienced a myocardial infarction at the age of 68.  Social history includes being widowed for three years with one daughter living in another state and he is a retiree from local transportation company as a bus driver.  Co-existing conditions include obesity with a body mass index (BMI) of 32 kg/m2  DMT2 with poor glycemic control (recent HbA1c of 9%)  and moderate renal dysfunction (Creatinine 1.8 mg/dl; GFR 45 ml/min/m2  indicative of CKD stage 3).  Upon examination  he looked pale and diaphoretic. Cardiac examination revealed elevated JVP  an S3 gallop  a displaced and forceful apex beat. Respiratory examination revealed bilateral crackles extending up to the upper half of the lung fields. His lower limbs showed bilateral pitting edema.  This presentation is congruent with decompensated systolic heart failure (HF).This patient group (older African American males) is known to have a high prevalence of HF  as several studies have shown an increased burden of HF and associated risk factors in African Americans. His longstanding  uncontrolled hypertension and DMT2 are notable contributing factors to his heart condition.  An immediate comprehensive management plan including investigations  treatment  and long-term follow-up would be needed for this patient.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 65 year-old African-American male who presents to the clinic with chief complaints of progressive shortness of breath upon exertion and swelling in his lower extremities over the past month. He also reports intermittent episodes of orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He has noticed a decrease in appetite and inadvertent weight loss. He denies chest pain or discomfort but has experienced bouts of palpitation.  Mr. Johnson has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes lisinopril and metformin respectively. He was a former smoker and quit seven years ago but has a 20 pack-year history of smoking. He also reports occasional alcohol use. He does not exercise and has a history of poor diet. His father died of a heart attack in his early seventies.   Upon physical examination  bilateral pedal edema up to the shin was noted and crackles were auscultated in the lower lung fields. He was also noted to have an elevated jugular venous pulse. His BMI was calculated to be 30  indicative of obesity.  Given the symptomatology  clinical findings  and relevant past medical history significant for risk factors for heart function deterioration  Mr. Johnson’s clinical presentation is suggestive of heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James is a 67-year-old African American male from a low socioeconomic background  presenting to the emergency department with chief complaints of exertional shortness of breath and worsening limb swelling for the past week. He reports that he has gained 10 lbs in the last two weeks. He also mentions waking up in the middle of the night due to breathlessness that is resolved when sitting up. These symptoms have progressively worsened over the past few days. Mr. James has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and myocardial infarction three years ago  for which he had undergone a percutaneous coronary intervention. He mentions that he has been non-compliant with his medications due to financial constraints. His family history is notable for his father who died of myocardial infarction at age 70. He quit smoking 10 years ago and consumes alcohol socially.  This case presentation reflects the significantly higher incidence of heart failure in African American individuals  older age groups  and individuals with comorbidities like diabetes  hypertension and ischemic heart disease which are recognized heart failure risk factors. The demographic information  past medical history  and lifestyle factors further align with literature on social determinants of health and outcomes in heart failure. Non-compliance to medications due to financial constraints represents another aspect of health disparities in heart failure management and outcomes. The reported symptoms and signs are consistent with congestive heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 72-year-old Hispanic male with a primary concern of persistent dyspnea associated with reducing exercise tolerance over the past few months. He is a retired school teacher and lives with his wife. He presents with a productive cough of white sputum and significant swelling in both lower limbs. He has occasionally been experiencing palpitations and episodes of dizziness.  His past medical history includes a diagnosis of ischemic heart disease eight years ago. He has also been living with type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years and hypertension for around 20 years. He underwent a angioplasty three years ago. He has been a non-smoker for the last 10 years but admits to having smoked 1 pack per day for approximately 30 years prior to that. Mr. Smith limits his alcohol consumption to the occasional glass of red wine with dinner.   Previously  Mr. Smith was quite active  enjoying regular walks with his wife and gardening. However  recently his exercise capacity has progressively decreased. He now reports that he struggles to walk past the driveway without becoming dyspneic and having to rest.   Medications include daily metformin and atorvastatin  and lisinopril and metoprolol  as prescribed.  Family history is significant for coronary artery disease in his father who died at the age of 67. His mother had type 2 diabetes mellitus and lived into her late 80's. His only sibling  an older brother  is healthy and quite active.  Mr. Smith's weight has increased by 10 lbs over the past month despite no significant changes in diet. He follows up regularly with his primary care physician but came to the emergency department today because of increasing breathlessness and leg swelling.   On examination  he is alert and oriented with a BMI of 27. Vitals show a heart rate of 88 bpm  blood pressure of 135/85mmHg  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and SpO2 of 95% on room air. Auscultation reveals bilateral basilar inspiratory crackles. There are also signs of peripheral edema in the lower extremities.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is an African American male  aged 65 years  presenting with chronic breathlessness  progressive exercise intolerance and intermittent episodes of acute pulmonary edema. He has gained weight (6 lbs in the past month) with notable lower limb edema. The patient reports awakening at night with shortness of breath (paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea).   Demographics:  Mr. Jackson Samuels  unemployed  divorced  with two adult children. He has a 20 pack-year smoking history but quit smoking 10 years ago. Syracuse  NY- born and raised  has lived in low-income housing for the past five years since his divorce. He admits to occasional alcohol usage  but no illicit drug use.   Past Medical History:  History of poorly controlled hypertension for the past 10 years and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed at the age of 45. Mr. Samuels admits poor medication adherence due to financial constraints. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years back with suboptimal recovery  and mild kidney disease diagnosed on routine blood workup one year back.   Family History:  His mother died of stroke and his father died of a heart attack. His younger brother has hypertension and his elder sister has type 2 diabetes and hypertension.   Summary:  We have here a 65 year-old African American male with a history of poorly controlled hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  a previous myocardial infarction and early stages of kidney disease  now presenting with symptoms suggestive of heart failure.

Patient Presentation: A 67-year-old African American male patient presents to the clinic complaining of increasing shortness of breath  fatigue  and swelling in his ankles and legs over the past two months. The symptoms have become more pronounced in the last week. He also reports a recent unintentional weight gain of approximately seven pounds. He describes his dyspnea as particularly uncomfortable when lying flat  often waking him up at night  causing him to sleep in a reclining chair recently. He denies chest pain  palpitations or dizziness but admits having little appetite.  Past Medical History: He has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed on Lisinopril and Metformin respectively. The patient has been non-compliant with his medications due to financial difficulties. He quit smoking 10 years ago  but has a 30-pack year history. He is also obese with a BMI of 32 and has a family history of heart disease (father).  Relevant para-clinical data: Blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg  heart rate regular at 88 bpm  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation reveals an S3 gallop. Lung auscultation exhibits crackles at both lung bases. Lower extremities exhibit bilateral 2+ pitting edema.   This demographic aligns with epidemiological data that suggests heart failure is most common in elderly patients  more prevalent in men  and particularly prevalent among the African American population. The patient's history of hypertension  diabetes  prior smoking  obesity  and family history of heart disease are common risk factors for heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Johnson is a 64-year-old African American female presenting with increased shortness of breath  progressive fatigue  and noticeable lower extremity swelling. These symptoms have been persistent for the past 2 weeks and have been progressively worsening. She reports a weight gain of about 5 pounds during this period. She admits to decreased physical activity due to fatigue and occasional chest discomfort.   Mrs. Johnson has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is managed with Metformin  as well as high blood pressure  managed with Lisinopril. She recently was diagnosed with left ventricular hypertrophy during a routine follow up with her primary care doctor 2 months ago. She is a former smoker with a 15 pack-year history but quit approximately 5 years ago. Her family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  including her father who had a Myocardial Infarction (MI) at 66.   The patient's regular diet is high in salt and fat. She has a BMI of 32. She reports non-compliance with her medications due to forgetfulness and is inconsistent with her appointments with her primary care doctor. She lives alone with minimal support from family members.  Mrs. Johnson works as a school bus driver but is currently on sick leave due to her condition. She denies illicit drug use  alcohol consumption is occasional and she has no known drug allergies.  On examination  she has bilateral pitting edema up to the mid-shins  elevated jugular venous pulse  and crackles at the bases of both lungs on auscultation. Her blood pressure is 145/85 and heart rate is irregular at 102 beats per minute. The EKG shows signs of previous myocardial damage.   Given her symptomatology  along with her medical history  this could potentially indicate further progression of heart disease  leading to heart failure. The irregular heart rate suggests further potential complications such as atrial fibrillation. She will require further investigations including blood tests  and imaging  and likely intensification of her medical management  as well as close follow up.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson  a 68-year-old African American female  presents to the clinic today with complaints of increasing shortness of breath  fatigue  and lower extremity swelling over the last month. She reports that her symptoms are progressively worsening  incapacitating her from performing her daily activities.  Ms. Johnson has a significant medical history that includes type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and obesity. She was diagnosed with diabetes 8 years ago and hypertension 10 years ago. Her body mass index (BMI) is 32 (obese  class I). In terms of family history  her father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and her mother passed away due to stroke at 78.  Ms. Johnson is a retired teacher living alone in her own home. She has two daughters who visit her frequently. She denies smoking and alcohol intake. Her compliance to medications and dietary restrictions are inconsistent due to frequent forgetfulness and her limited fixed income. She does not do regular exercise as she gets tired easily. She reports no known drug allergies.  Ms. Johnson's symptom of progressive fatigue  dyspnea  and lower extremity edema coupled with her comorbidities and family history suggest a potential decompensation of heart failure. Further diagnostic work-up is warranted to rule in/out heart failure and manage her appropriately.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 73-year-old African American male who presents with worsening shortness of breath and fatigue over the last few weeks. He reports increased difficulty performing daily activities such as climbing stairs or walking short distances. He has increasing swelling in his legs and has noticed a recent unexplained weight gain of about five pounds.   He also reports occasional chest discomfort  nocturnal cough and being awoken at night due to breathlessness. He admits to orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND). Patient's chronic symptoms have exacerbated over the past 4 days and are unrelieved by rest or home medications.  Past medical history includes hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and coronary artery disease. His current medications include metoprolol  lisinopril  and aspirin. His BMI is 31 and he admits to having used alcohol and cigarettes heavily in the past  though he quit both 10 years ago.   There is family history of heart disease  particularly his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 67. His socio-economic status is low  he is a retired construction worker living on social security.  Discussion:  This patient presentation is reflective of the type of patient who may suffer from heart failure. Older age  male gender  African American ethnicity  and low socio-economic status are all risk factors for heart failure. Certain medical conditions such as hypertension  diabetes and coronary artery disease can lead to heart failure. This patient's history of heavy alcohol use and smoking could have also contributed to his risk. Finally  the symptoms reported by the patient—including dyspnea  fatigue  lower extremity edema  weight gain  and nocturnal symptoms—are all consistent with a presentation of heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jackson  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic complaining of shortness of breath  fatigue and swelling in his ankles. The patient states that these symptoms have been progressing over the past week  and he has had trouble doing normal activities due to weakness and breathlessness. He also reports a weight gain of five pounds over the same period.  Background Info:  Mr. Jackson has a past medical history of poorly controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus over the past 10 years. He also has a history of smoking  approximately a pack per day for the past 30 years  but he quit 5 years ago. His father passed away from heart disease at the age of 60.  Current Medications:  Mr. Jackson's current medication includes Metformin 500 mg twice daily for diabetes  Lisinopril 10 mg daily for hypertension  and Simvastatin 20 mg daily for hypercholesterolemia.  Demographics:  He is a retired manufacturing worker and lives with his wife in a small suburban house. He admits not following a strict diet and states his lack of physical activity as he has been feeling too weak for the past few weeks.  This presentation is in line with the fact that African Americans are disproportionately affected by heart failure  particularly at younger ages compared to other races. Untreated hypertension and moderately controlled diabetes are major risk factors. His history of smoking and family history of cardiac disease further increases his risk.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  orthopnea  swollen ankles  and fatigue. He has experienced increasing symptoms over the past several days. The patient has not been taking his prescribed medications consistently due to financial constraints  which is commonly reported among economically disadvantaged populations.  Past Medical History:  Previously diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes mellitus  for which he is prescribed lisinopril and metformin  respectively. He also has a 20 pack-year smoking history  having quit 10 years ago. He had a myocardial infarction five years ago  treated with angioplasty with stent placement and medical therapy.   Demographics:  The patient is retired  lives with his wife  and is a grandfather of four. He reports a compromised diet  intermittently eating high sodium and high-fat foods and difficulty engaging in physical activities due to knee osteoarthritis. He is uninsured and presents significant concerns about medication and healthcare costs.  This example patient presentation reflects the overrepresentation of heart failure in older  African-American people with lower socioeconomic status  as shown in the literature. Also  the representation of comorbidities such as hypertension  diabetes  and previous myocardial infarction is accurate according to common risk factors present in this patient population with heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Angela Freeman is a 62-year-old African-American woman who presents to the clinic with complaints of increased shortness of breath on exertion  fatigue  and swelling in her lower extremities over the past three weeks. The patient reports that she needs three pillows to sleep in bed comfortably  which is a change from her regular one-pillow setup. She also mentions frequent nocturia which is disrupting her sleep.   Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. She is a non-smoker but admits to a diet high in sodium and occasional alcohol consumption. She has a family history of coronary artery disease and her father had congestive heart failure.   Ms. Freeman has been managing her hypertension and diabetes with prescribed medications  Lisinopril 20mg once daily  and Metformin 500mg twice daily. However  she admits to not always taking her medicines regularly in the past month due to financial constraints.   Her vitals on presentation includes a BP of 150/90 mmHg  Pulse- 85 bpm  RR – 22 breaths per minute  SpO2– 95% on room air.  Physical examination reveals crepitant rales at the bases of the lungs  elevated JVP  mild hepatomegaly  and 2+ pitting edema in lower extremities. An EKG is ordered which shows left ventricular hypertrophy with strain pattern.  Based on the clinical presentation and her high-risk profile having hypertension  family history of CAD and non-adherence to antihypertensive medication  a preliminary diagnosis of heart failure is made. Further critical investigations include echocardiography and serum B-Type Natriuretic Peptide to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Clara Johnson  an 75-year-old African American female  presented to the clinic with a chief complaint of increased fatigue  shortness of breath on exertion  and periodic swelling of her lower extremities. These symptoms have been persisting over the last month and gradually increasing in severity.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Johnson has a complex medical history that includes hypertension  controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a recent history of myocardial infarction (six months ago). She also has a history of early-stage breast cancer  treated 15 years ago  with no recurrence. She does not have any known allergies. The patient has been adherent to treatment for her chronic conditions which includes metformin  lisinopril  and aspirin. She does not smoke or drinks only socially.  Socioeconomic Situation:  Mrs. Johnson is retired and lives alone in her home  located in an urban area. She has two adult children living out of state. She uses a home health aid service for assistance with daily activities. Her lifestyle is generally sedentary.  Vitals and Examination:  On physical examination  Mrs. Johnson's blood pressure was 146/92 mmHg  her pulse was 80 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation was 94% on room air  and BMI was 30 indicating obesity. Upon examination  she displayed distended jugular veins and pitting edema in her lower extremities. She also had rales in the lower lobes of both lungs.  These findings  along with the patient’s history  make congestive heart failure a probable diagnosis. Further diagnostic studies  such as an echocardiogram or a chest X-ray  should be performed to confirm this potential diagnosis and rule out other causes of her symptoms.

Patient Information: Mrs. Sheila Anderson  female  75-year-old  Caucasian  retired schoolteacher  married  non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumption  resident of Seattle  Washington.  Chief Complaint: Shortness of breath  chronic fatigue  swelling in legs and ankles  persistent cough  weight gain  and occasional rapid heart beating.  History of Present Illness: Patient reports progressive shortness of breath over the last six months  notably worse while lying flat or during moderate physical activities. She mentions chronic fatigue that limits her regular activities. Additionally  Mrs. Anderson noticed lower extremity edema and unanticipated weight gain in the past two months. She also experiences intermittent rapid heart beating and a cough that is worse at night. Mrs. Anderson admits compliance issues with her prescribed medications due to memory problems.  Past Medical History: History of hypertension for the past 15 years and type 2 diabetes for 10 years; both managed with medications. Mrs. Anderson also had a myocardial infarction (heart attack) eight years ago  which was treated with angioplasty and stent placement. She has been prescribed aspirin  a beta-blocker  and a statin since then. Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease; her mother had a stroke at the age of 68 and her father had heart failure  passing away at the age of 78.  Physical Examination: Brought in by her daughter. Patient is alert but appears fatigued. Blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  heart rate 85 bpm  respiratory rate 20 bpm  and O2 saturation 94% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals an S3 heart sound. Pulmonary examination shows bilateral crackles at the lung bases. Lower extremities reveal 2+ pitting edema up to the level of the knees.  The above clinical presentation is suggestive of chronic heart failure.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Hernandez  a 72-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the primary care clinic with complaints of progressively worsening shortness of breath particularly when lying down at night or with minimal exertion (like walking to the bathroom)  decreased exercise tolerance  and recurrent lower extremity swelling for the past two months. He also reports increased fatigability  frequent night-time urination  and unintentional weight gain.  He has been diagnosed with uncontrolled type 2 diabetes and hypertension for the past 15 years and has a history of prior myocardial infarction 7 years ago. He admits to being non-compliant with medications and diet adjustments due to financial constraints. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history and used alcohol in a social context.  The patient is a retired janitor  widowed  and lives alone. His son drops in twice a week to help with groceries and check on him. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father having died due to heart attack at the age of 65.   Considering his age  ethnicity  male gender  history of hypertension  diabetes  prior myocardial infarction  and non-compliance with medications  his presentation is typical of heart failure. His lifestyle and socio-economic background  including smoking  past alcohol use  and lack of comprehensive healthcare access  further contribute to his risk.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Antonio Vega  a 67-year-old African American male  is appearing for an appointment in your office. He reports increasing exertions over the last two months  describing it as ""feeling winded"" with moderate activity such as walking a few blocks or climbing a flight of stairs. He also states that he has been waking up in the night feeling short of breath.  He has noticed some swelling in his ankles and abdomen and does admit to an increase in his weight  about 7 pounds over the last month. His wife reports that he seems more fatigued  has been increasingly irritable  and has had a decrease in appetite. He denies chest pain  palpitations  orthopnea  or other associated symptoms.   Regarding his past medical history  Mr. Vega was diagnosed with hypertension 12 years ago for which he has been on Losartan 50 mg daily. He also has a history of smoking approximately 1 pack a day for 30 years  though he quit 10 years ago. There is no known history of diabetes  no significant surgical history  and no drug allergies.   Family history reveals a father who died of myocardial infarction at the age of 62 and a mother with stroke at age 70. He leads a fairly sedentary lifestyle  works as a CCTV operator  and consumes alcohol socially.  On physical examination: - Acute distress: negative - Vital signs: elevated blood pressure (150/90 mmHg); pulse: 98 bpm; respiratory rate: 20 breaths/minute; O2 Sat: 96% on room air; BMI: 27 - Cardiovascular exam: Normal S1 and S2 heart sounds; S3 gallop heard; no murmurs; jugular venous distention is noticed - Pulmonary exam: reduced breath sounds at lung bases; no wheezes or crackles - Extremities: 2+ edema of lower extremities.  The potential diagnosis of heart failure may be discussed based on these findings.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson is a 68-year-old African-American woman who presents with complaints of shortness of breath on exertion and fatigue over the last month. She states that her dyspnea is particularly noticeable when she tries to climb stairs or do household chores  and she's had to rest multiple times due to breathlessness. Additionally  she reports a decreased tolerance for physical activities compared to before. She also notes occasional paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and orthopnea.  She has a past medical history significant for hypertension which was diagnosed 12 years ago and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 8 years ago. Both conditions are moderately controlled with medications. She's a non-smoker  but reports a history of heavy alcohol consumption in her youth. Her diet is predominantly high sodium Southern-style cuisine. She has not had regular exercise due to arthritis. Her family history is significant for her father  who had heart failure in his late-sixties  and a brother with early-onset coronary artery disease.  On physical examination  she presents with an overweight physique  mild bilateral lower extremity edema and her lungs have bibasilar crackles. No cyanosis is noted. Her BP on presentation is 145/90 mmHg  pulse 80/min. Basic laboratory results show elevated levels of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP).  Given her symptoms  physical examination findings  past medical and family history  ageing  and elevated BNP  Ms. Johnson has clinical manifestations suggestive of heart failure. She is at high risk considering reported risk factors include age  ethnicity  male sex  family history  hypertension  diabetes  and a sedentary lifestyle. Prompt diagnostic evaluation  including echocardiogram and electrocardiogram  and management plan in accordance with current guidelines is warranted.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 67-year-old African American male named Mr. Johnson  presenting with a recurring complaint of shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasionally ankle swelling  specifically noticed after indulging in high salt meals. Mr. Johnson reports increased sleep disruption due to frequent urination during nights. He has a current body mass index of 29 and is a non-smoker.  Relevant past medical history revealed that Mr. Johnson is hypertensive and has been on thiazide diuretics for the past 20 years  with sporadic compliance. He has also been diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus for 15 years  managed with metformin. A decade ago  he was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease Stage 3 due to his longstanding hypertension and diabetes. His father and elder brother also had a history of heart failure.  Lifestyle: Mr. Johnson is a retired school bus driver who plays an active role in a local church. He admits to a high-salt diet that includes regular consumption of processed and fast foods.  The above factors place Mr. Johnson with higher risk of heart failure due to his age  race (African American men have higher rates of heart failure)  hypertension  type 2 diabetes  chronic kidney disease  family history of heart failure  and obesity.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Brown is a 67-year-old African American male  presenting to the clinic with progressive shortness of breath  severe fatigue  and noticeable weight gain in the last two to three months. Mr. Brown is a former factory worker and has recently retired. He reports that these symptoms have been gradually worsening over the past few weeks and are now affecting his ability to perform normal activities such as walking short distances and even dressing himself. He also mentions frequent nocturnal urination.  Mr. Brown has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which have been managed with lisinopril and metformin respectively for the past 15 years. He also had a myocardial infarction approximately 5 years ago. Mr. Brown admits he used to smoke a pack of cigarettes daily for about 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He admits to consuming alcohol but only socially.   He is currently living with his wife in their own home. His wife is assisting him with his day-to-day activities since he started experiencing these symptoms. Mr. Brown admits to a family history of heart disease; his father had died of a heart attack.   On physical examination  he is found to be overweight with a BMI of 30 kg/m2. He appears visibly fatigued. Cardiac examination reveals an audible S3 sound and his lungs have crackles at the bases suggesting fluid overload. Peripheral examination shows 2+ pitting edema in both lower extremities up to the level of the mid-shins.   This scenario represents a typical clinical presentation of a patient with heart failure.

Patient Presentation:   Patient is a 67-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department with a chief complaint of breathlessness and swelling in legs. He notes onset of his symptoms over the past month  but states they have worsened in the past week. On further questioning  he also admits to a weight gain of 10 pounds during the same period  and increased fatigue making it difficult for him to perform his usual tasks. He denies chest pain  but reports difficulty lying flat due to breathlessness that improves with sitting up.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Patient has a known history of long-standing hypertension for 15 years which is inconsistently controlled  and a more recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes for the past 5 years. He also has a 20 pack-year smoking history  although he quit smoking 10 years ago. He denies any known history of coronary artery disease but had been diagnosed with obesity. The patient's father had also died of congestive heart failure.  Relevant Medications: The patient is on Lisinopril 20mg daily  Metformin 1000mg twice daily  and Atorvastatin 10mg daily.   This case underlines key demographic trends seen in heart failure patients  including higher prevalence seen in elderly  African American individuals  and in those with poorly controlled co-morbid conditions such as hypertension and diabetes. A history of smoking and family history of heart failure also increase the risk.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jackson Davis  a 67-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic with complaints of unrelieved shortness of breath  chronic fatigue  and persistent cough producing white sputum. He also reports persistent swelling in his ankles  feet  legs  and occasionally in his abdomen. The patient has a body mass index (BMI) of 30.5 and is therefore classified as obese.  He has a significant medical history that includes type 2 diabetes mellitus (managed with Metformin)  hypertension (on Lisinopril)  and a prior myocardial infarction 5 years ago. He has a 40-pack year history of smoking  although he quit 4 years ago post his myocardial infarction.  He has not been adhering to dietary sodium restriction and regularly consumes over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for osteoarthritis-related pain  which may also be contributing to his symptoms.  On review of systems  he denies chest pain  fever  or recent changes in weight  but does report occasional episodes of nocturnal dyspnea. Family history is significant for early-onset coronary artery disease in both his father (died of a myocardial infarction at age 64) and a brother (diagnosed with atherosclerosis at age 58).  Mr. Davis' physical exam reveals an increased heart rate  jugular vein distention  bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation  displaced cardiac apex  and 2+ lower bilateral extremity edema. His blood pressure is 155/92  and his pulse is 98 beats per minute.  Considering his demographic details  risk factor burden  past medical history and findings on physical exam  Mr. Davis' presentation raises a high level of suspicion for heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Ortiz is a 72-year-old Hispanic female who presented to the emergency department with a 48-hour history of progressively worsening shortness of breath  fatigue  and orthopnea. The patient mentions she has noticed swelling in her ankles and feet for the last one week. She has been feeling unusually tired  particularly after moderate physical activity. She also complaints of a new-onset non-productive cough.  Ms. Ortiz is a widow  lives alone in a single-story house  and is independent with all her Activities of Daily Living (ADLs). She has never smoked and her alcohol intake is minimal. She has a low-salt  low-fat diet with intermittent compliance.  Her past medical history includes hypertension diagnosed ten years ago and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed five years ago  both conditions are largely controlled with medication. Ms. Ortiz has been on Lisinopril 20mg daily for her hypertension and Metformin 500mg BID for diabetes. She has no known allergies.  Family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. Her mother died of a stroke at the age of 75 and her brother had a heart attack in his early 60s.  On examination  she has a blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  heart rate of 95 bpm  respiratory rate of 20 per minute  and room air oxygen saturation of 92%. On cardiac auscultation  there is a third heart sound with no audible murmurs. Her lung fields have crackles in the lower one-third on both sides. Bilateral pitting edema is present in her ankles.  This presentation is consistent with congestive heart failure. She has several risk factors  including her advanced age  a personal history of hypertension  diabetes  and a family history of cardiovascular disease.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Greene  a 70-year-old African American woman  presents to the Emergency Department complaining of worsening shortness of breath  fatigue  and lower extremity swelling over the past week. She reports that she finds it progressively harder to carry out her daily activities and has to sleep propped up on pillows due to difficulty in breathing when she lies flat. She also mentions a significant decrease in urine output.   Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus. She has no known drug allergies. She is a non-smoker and takes lisinopril and metformin. A review of prior records reveals poor compliance with medications and a non-optimized blood pressure last seen 3 months ago in a community health center. She has no known family history of heart disease. She is divorced  lives alone  primarily consumes a high-sodium diet and has low physical activity levels.  On physical examination  she appears dyspneic. She has an irregularly irregular pulse  elevated jugular venous pressure and bilateral pitting lower limb edema up to the knees. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral basal crackles. Her blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate is 110 beats per minute irregular  and respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute.  Given her presentation  physical examination findings and past medical history  she is likely suffering from congestive heart failure (CHF)  potentially precipitated by uncontrolled hypertension. She will require prompt therapeutic intervention and further diagnostic evaluation including an EKG  chest radiograph  and cardiac biomarker assessment to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of her heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Michael Evans  an African-American man aged 65 years old  presents to the clinic today with complaints of increasing shortness of breath  fatigue  and noted swelling in his legs and ankles over the last few weeks. He reports he finds it increasingly difficult to carry out normal activities  such as walking short distances or doing light housework.   He is retired  a former truck driver  and currently lives alone after the recent passing of his wife. He is a non-smoker but reports a past history of heavy alcohol consumption until he quit about 15 years ago. He is not on any current medications.   His past medical history reveals that he was diagnosed as hypertensive and diabetic 5 years ago for which he was advised lifestyle modifications since he has not been consistent with follow-ups.   Mr. Evans represents an at-risk demographic for heart failure  consisting of over 65 years old  African American  and having a previous history of hypertension and diabetes. His symptoms match that of progressing heart failure  requiring prompt further evaluation and treatment.  Mr. Evans's history of heavy alcohol use also contributes to his risk representation for the condition.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Robert Hernandez is a 65-year-old Hispanic male who presents to the emergency department complaining of increasing shortness of breath  fatigue and lower-extremity edema over the past week. He reports that he has been unable to lay flat to sleep and has been sleeping on 3 pillows. In addition  he notes a recent unplanned weight gain of 7 pounds  despite a decrease in his food intake due to a loss of appetite.  He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  a myocardial infarction (MI) three years ago and high cholesterol. His medications include metoprolol  lisinopril  furosemide  aspirin  atorvastatin  and metformin. He previously smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 40 years but quit after his MI. He consumes alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use. His family history is significant for ischemic heart disease as his father died from MI at the age of 66.  On examination  he appears distressed. Vital signs show blood pressure 165/90 mmHg  heart rate 96 beats/minute  respiratory rate 28 breaths/minute  temperature 37C  and oxygen saturation 90% while breathing ambient air. Upon auscultation  there are bibasilar crackles noted in lungs  heart sounds include an S3  and there is faint pitting edema up to the level of the shins bilaterally. Additionally  jugular venous pressure is elevated at 10 cm H2O while at a 30-degree incline.  Given Mr. Hernandez's history of cardiovascular disease and his presenting symptoms  a preliminary diagnosis of decompensated systolic heart failure was made. Following admission  further diagnostic tests would be required to confirm this diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Peter Thompson  a 76-year-old African American male from Chicago  Illinois  presented with generalized fatigue  shortness of breath  and persistent edema of the lower extremities. He reported a significant weight gain over the past few weeks and acknowledged difficulty in sleeping unless in an upright position. He also complained of infrequent bouts of chest discomfort and palpitations.  His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) for which he has been on Metformin and Glimepiride for the past 20 years. He has had moderate hypertension for the last 10 years  and it has been relatively well controlled with Lisinopril. His father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  suggesting a potential familial risk. Thompson has a 40-pack-year history of smoking  although he quit smoking ten years ago. His diet is typical of the standard American diet  high in salt and fat.  Thompson has a BMI of 30 and is otherwise sedentary with minimal physical activity. He lives alone after his wife expired five years ago. Thompson also shared that he has moderate problems with adherence to prescribed medications due to forgetting and his complex regimen associated with multiple conditions.  Current medications include Metformin 500mg twice daily  Glimepiride 2mg once daily  Lisinopril 10mg once daily  and Aspirin 81mg daily for cardiovascular prophylaxis.   His current clinical presentation combined with his past medical history suggesting a possible diagnosis of Heart Failure. This will require confirmation through further tests  including echocardiography and cardiac biomarkers.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Jessica Brown is a 68-year-old African American female  presenting with increasing fatigue and noticeable shortness of breath  particularly during mild physical activities over the past few months. She also reports periodic swollen ankles and waking up in the middle of the night feeling breathless.   She lives with her husband in an urban area  is retired  and her family's income is at the lower range constituting her status as below the poverty line. She does not smoke but has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. Her diet majorly comprises fast food due to poor access to fresh produce in her neighborhood.   Her past medical history is significant for hypertension  which has been controlled with medication for the past 15 years and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 10 years with suboptimal control due to medication non-adherence. She has been hospitalized once for a heart attack five years ago but refused rehabilitative care due to financial constraints.   Her medication list includes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Aspirin. However  she has reported non-adherence to the prescribed medical treatment due to financial barriers and side effects which she has been experiencing. She has a family history of heart disease  with her father having succumbed to heart failure in his early 70s.  Physical examination reveals an overweight woman with a body mass index of 30. Blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg and pulse rate is 85 beats per minute. Auscultation of the chest reveals bibasilar crackles and a S3 gallop. Lower extremity examination shows 2+ pitting edema bilaterally.  Ms. Brown fits the demographic representation of a typical heart failure patient as found in literature  which indicates a high prevalence of heart failure among older  African American women with a history of cardiovascular disease  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes. The impact of socioeconomic factors on her overall healthcare is also evident in her case.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Samuel Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic with symptoms of increasing shortness of breath  persistent cough  rapid weight gain of about 7 pounds in the past two weeks  and noticeable swelling in his feet  ankles  and abdomen. He reports occasionally experiencing lack of appetite but increased stomach discomfort. He denies any chest pain  but says he feels a consistent rapid or irregular heartbeat.   Mr. Rodriguez is a retired construction worker  who spends most of his time at home due to his symptoms. He has been a smoker for about 40 years and moderately drinks alcohol. He has a family history of heart diseases  with his father having died from a heart attack in his early 70s and an older brother currently battling hypertension.  His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes for which he takes Metformin and Glipizide  and COPD  which was diagnosed 5 years back  for which he uses a steroid inhaler. He is also on a stable dose of atorvastatin for high cholesterol.  Mr. Rodriguez had a stroke with minimal residual speech difficulties about 1 year ago. His last checkup was six months ago when his diabetes was reported as well-controlled. He has no known drug allergies.  The patient represents a common demographic - elderly  Hispanic and male  for heart failure. His history of long-term smoking  presence of type 2 diabetes  stroke and COPD are also consistent risk factors for heart failure.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Davidson Age: 78 Gender: Male Race/Ethnicity: African-American  Chief Complaint: Mr. Davidson presents with a two-week history of increasing fatigue  cough  and shortness of breath  particularly when exercising and lying down. He also reports swelling in his legs and has noticed some unintentional weight gain  which he attributes to the swelling.   Demographic Details: Mr. Davidson is a retired auto mechanic  living in urban Detroit with his wife. He is a former smoker  with a 30-pack year history of smoking but quit over 25 years ago. He admits to a diet high in sodium. His family history includes heart disease; his father had a myocardial infarction in his sixties.  Past Medical History: Past health history reveals hypertension and type 2 diabetes for which he's currently taking lisinopril and metformin respectively. His hypertension has been poorly controlled. His last visit to his primary care physician was 8 months ago. He had previously been advised to reduce his sodium intake and increase physical activity  but he admits non-compliance  finding these changes difficult to implement.  Observations: On physical examination  Mr. Davidson demonstrates pitting edema in the lower legs and his lung examination reveals rales at the bases. His blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg  pulse 98 bpm  and he has gained 10 pounds in the last month.  Patient's current symptoms  lifestyle  and medical history indicate possible heart failure  likely requiring further diagnostic investigation including lab work and echocardiography.

Patient Presentation  Ms. Maria Garcia  a 72-year-old Hispanic female presents to the clinic with complaints of increasing shortness of breath over the past two to three weeks. She describes the dyspnea as particularly noticeable during mild-to-moderate exertion but also present at rest. She reports episodes of nocturnal dyspnea that have caused her to sleep with three pillows to relieve the symptoms. She also mentions experiencing persistent fatigue  decreased exercise tolerance  and swelling in her ankles and feet.   Ms. Garcia has a history of chronic hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which have been managed with medications for the past 20 years. She experienced a myocardial infarction five years ago. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. Her medications include Lisinopril  Metformin  and Metoprolol. She has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with her father passing away from myocardial infarction at age 65  and her older brother diagnosed with heart failure two years ago.   On physical examination  Ms. Garcia is obese with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32. She appears dyspneic and ill-at-ease. Heart sounds reveal a gallop rhythm (S3 heart sound). There is pulmonary rales present on auscultation. She has pitting edema on her lower extremities up to the level of her shins.  Based on her symptoms and medical history  heart failure is suspected. Further diagnostic tests like EKG  chest X-ray  CBC  CMP  and echocardiogram have been ordered.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Santos is a 72-year-old Hispanic male presenting with complaints of increasing dyspnea on exertion  orthopnea and episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea over the past few weeks. He also reports swelling of his legs and difficulty fitting into his shoes  suggestive of peripheral edema. Recently  he has noticed a weight gain but claims he has not changed his diet. Additionally  he reports fatigue and occasional lightheadedness.   His past medical history includes hypertension diagnosed twenty years ago and type II diabetes diagnosed ten years ago. Both conditions are being managed with medication  although adherence to the prescribed regimen is inconsistent. He underwent a diagnostic cardiac catheterization five years ago where non-obstructive coronary artery disease was detected.   He is a former smoker  having quit smoking 15 years ago after a 30-pack year smoking history. He acknowledges a history of moderate alcohol consumption but has abstained for the last one year. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in sodium and fats.   Family history is significant for heart disease; his father passed away from a myocardial infarction in his 60s  and his older brother was recently diagnosed with congestive heart failure.    His current medications include Metformin 1000mg twice daily  Lisinopril 20mg once daily and a daily low dose aspirin. On examination  he has an elevated jugular venous pressure and crackles on lung auscultation  suggestive of pulmonary congestion. Bilateral pitting edema of lower extremities is also noticeable up to his shins.  Given his symptoms and physical findings  he is suspected to have heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Ricardo Torres  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic complaining of increased shortness of breath on exertion  fatigue  and swelling in his legs over the past few weeks. He also reports to have orthopnea  mentioning that he uses three pillows to help him breathe at night. In addition  he has been noticing a decrease in appetite because he feels full very quickly.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are managed with medications. He was previously advised to follow a low-salt diet combined with moderate physical activities. He is former smoker and quit 10 years ago. On inquiry  he admits non-compliance with both his diet and medications over the past month due to personal stress.   His family history reveals his father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 72 and his mother currently has congestive heart failure. He is retired  lives with his wife  and has three adult children.  On physical examination  he appears mildly dyspneic. His vital signs include blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg  heart rate of 85 bpm  respirations of 22 per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals an S3 and peripheral examination shows 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally. His body mass index is 32  indicating obesity. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Sandra Johnson is a 65-year-old African American woman who presents in the emergency room complaining of increased shortness of breath over the past three days. She reports experiencing worsening fatigue and feeling winded after simple daily activities like walking to the mailbox or cooking. Ms. Johnson also notes that she's been waking up at night gasping for breath. She also mentions noticeable swelling in her legs and feet  which is a new symptom for her.  Ms. Johnson has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which have been largely managed by medication for the last five years. She is also a former smoker  quitting approximately 15 years ago  but had a substantial pack-year history prior to quitting. She admits to a poor diet high in sodium and lacks regular physical exercise due to her limited mobility.   Ms. Johnson takes metformin for her diabetes management and lisinopril for her hypertension. She is not known to have any allergies. She lives alone and is a retired elementary school teacher. Her only son lives out of state and visits periodically. She does not consume alcohol or use illicit drugs.   Family history is significant as her father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 67  and her mother has Type 2 diabetes. Both her older sisters have been diagnosed with hypertension and one has also been diagnosed with heart failure.   On physical examination  she is noted to be obese with a BMI of 32  with pitting edema in both lower extremities up to her mid-shin  and has notable jugular vein distention. Her breath sounds are diminished at lung bases and she has an irregular heart rate on auscultation. Her vitals at admission are BP 160/90 mm Hg  Heart rate 90 beats/min  Respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  Temperature 37°C (98.6°F)  and O2 saturation 94% on room air.   The combination of her symptoms  history  and physical findings lead to a suspicion of heart failure which requires immediate attention and further diagnostic evaluations for confirmation.

Patient Presentation:  A 74-year-old African American female presents to the emergency department with complaints of increasing shortness of breath  fatigue  palpitations  and swelling in her legs and feet. She states that these symptoms have been ongoing for the past few months  however  they have significantly worsened over the past week. She details a history of difficulty breathing when lying flat and has been sleeping in a recliner for relief.  Patient's relevant past medical history includes hypertension  which she was diagnosed with at age 50  and non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus  diagnosed at age 55. She has also had some episodes of angina which were relieved by rest. She is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago after a 30 year history of 1-pack/day. Patient denies any known history of heart disease in the family. She denies alcohol or recreational drug use.  She lives alone and has recently retired as a school teacher. She does not have regular physical activities and eats a diet high in salt and processed foods. Her Body Mass Index (BMI) is 30  indicating obesity.  The patient's current medications include Metformin 500 mg twice a day for diabetes  Lisinopril 10 mg once a day for hypertension  and a baby aspirin once a day as suggested by her primary care physician.   Given her age  race  gender  and past medical history  this patient is at significant risk for heart failure. Her current symptoms  lifestyle  and dietary choices adds to this risk profile  necessitating further diagnostic workup and therapeutic management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Lopez is a 65-year-old Hispanic male presenting to the clinic with worsening shortness of breath  especially with exertion in the last 1-2 months. The patient reports experiencing fatigue  reduced exercise tolerance  and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Mr. Lopez also mentions frequent nocturia and mild leg swelling  which have similarly worsened over this period.  He has a history of hypertension  which has been poorly controlled despite medication adjustments. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago. He also had a myocardial infarction five years prior  followed by successful percutaneous coronary intervention and has been on aspirin and statins since. The patient quit smoking after his heart attack but still enjoys a glass or two of wine a few times a week. He maintains a fairly sedentary lifestyle with a diet rich in sodium due to his preference for traditional Hispanic foods.   His mother died of heart disease in her 60s  and his older sister was recently diagnosed with heart failure. He denies chest pain  significant palpitation  or fainting. On examination  he has elevated jugular venous pressure  pitting edema in his legs  and auscultation reveals bilateral basal crackles. An EKG is planned to screen for any undiagnosed ischemic heart disease  and an echocardiogram to assess for heart failure. Currently  patient's BMI is 32  indicating obesity.   In summary  Mr. Lopez is a 65 year-old Hispanic male with significant cardiac risk factors and a family history of cardiac disease  now presenting with typical symptoms of heart failure. He likely represents the common epidemiological category for such a disease  given his ethnic background  age  poorly controlled risk factors  and lifestyle habits.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Santos  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with a two-week history of increasing shortness of breath  fatigued feeling  and swelling in his lower legs and ankles. He reports a persistent cough is making his nights uncomfortable  often waking up to urinate and experiencing increased heart palpitations.   His past medical history includes uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and a myocardial infarction eight years ago. Mr. Santos has a 30-year history of smoking but quit five years ago. He also admits he has not been adhering to his diabetic diet and medication over the last few months due to personal issues  resorting to higher salt intake and less physical activity.  He reports occasional alcohol use and is a retired office worker. He lives alone and has two adult children who live out of state. He is struggling with depression since his wife's demise two years ago. His father died with heart failure in his 70s  and his elder brother was diagnosed with heart disease in his early 60s.  Upon physical examination  peripheral pitting edema is noted in both his lower extremities and rales are heard at the bases of both lungs. Elevated jugular venous pulse is also observed. EKG suggests left ventricular hypertrophy. Subsequent Echocardiogram test shows reduced ejection fraction of 30% (normal range between 50% - 70 %) suggesting systolic dysfunction.
