He has been feeling bloated with swelling in his ankles and legs  which are worse by evening and relieves a bit with overnight rest. He also complained of a persistent cough with white sputum.  This patient presents a typical clinical scenario of Chronic Heart Failure (CHF) with reduced ejection fraction secondary to ischemic heart disease  in the setting of multiple risk factors like hypertension  Dyslipidaemia  diabetes  smoking history  and previous CABG.

Patient Representation:  A 72-year-old African-American male presents with chronic  worsening shortness of breath  fatigue  and lower extremity swelling of several weeks' duration. Previous medical history includes hypertension controlled with an ACE inhibitor and beta-blocker  type 2 diabetes managed with metformin  and a previous myocardial infarction at the age of 58. There is no known family history of heart disease. The patient has no known drug allergies. He reports that he quit smoking 10 years ago and only drinks alcohol occasionally. He avoids exercise due to his symptoms.   On physical examination  the patient appears tired and in moderate distress due to breathing difficulty. Vital signs reveal blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg  pulse of 82 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Auscultation reveals S3 gallop and lungs display diffuse crackles bilaterally. Lower extremities show 3+ pitting edema up to the mid-shins.   Summary: 72-year-old male with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and prior MI  presents with chronic  worsening dyspnea  fatigue  and lower extremities edema suggestive of congestive heart failure.

Patient Profile:  A 75-year-old African American male with a known medical history of hypertension  Type 2 diabetes mellitus  and past smoker presented to the clinic.  Presentation:  The patient complained of progressive exertional shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional episodes of light-headedness for the past three months. Recently  he noticed that lying flat makes his breathing difficulties worse and he now needs three pillows to sleep comfortably. He also reported swelling in his ankles and a weight gain of about 5 pounds over the past month. His wife noticed that he has been less alert and his memory is not as good recently.  Physical Examination:   Cardiovascular examination revealed an elevated jugular venous pressure  a displaced apex beat  and the presence of a third heart sound (S3). The lungs had bibasilar crackles. Pitting edema of both lower extremities was noted.  Relevant Medical History:   The patient has been on medication for hypertension and diabetes for the past 20 years. His last echocardiogram  two years back  showed mild left ventricular hypertrophy and ejection fraction of 50%. His current medication includes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Aspirin.  Considering the above presentation  symptoms  and medical history  the patient is showing signs consistent with progression to heart failure.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and BMI of 30 presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion  orthopnea  occasional dry cough  and lower extremity edema of one-week duration. He reports increasing fatigue and reduced physical activity. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distension and bilateral lung crackles. He denies chest pain  palpitations  or dizziness. He is a nonsmoker and non-alcoholic  and he has been on hydrochlorothiazide and metformin without compliance issues until now. There's no known family history of heart diseases.

Demographic Information:   A 72-year-old African-American male.  Medical History:  The patient has a substantial medical history that includes long-standing hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus. He also has chronic kidney disease due to diabetic nephropathy. He is a former smoker  having quit smoking 20 years ago. He has been adhering to his prescribed medication regimen which includes metformin  lisinopril  and amlodipine.   Presenting Symptoms:  The patient presents with a one-week history of progressive shortness of breath on exertion. He has also noted increased swelling in his legs (bilateral lower limb edema) and weight gain of about 5 pounds within the same time frame. He also reports an increased frequency of night-time urination (nocturia) and feeling wearier than usual with typical daily activities.   Based on demographics and symptoms  the patient's presentation is consistent with heart failure. This diagnosis is supported by his risk factors including advanced age  African-American ethnicity  uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and history of smoking.

Patient Information: 65-year-old African American male  Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and chronic kidney disease (stage 3) in the past. He is currently on medications for the same including Metformin  Lisinopril  and Hydrochlorothiazide. He also has a long-standing history of smoking (20 cigarettes per day for almost 40 years) although he quit 5 years ago.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient was brought to the emergency room with complains of progressive worsening of dyspnea on exertion and fatigue over a period of 6 weeks. He also reported notable weight gain and swelling in his ankles and legs. He noticed an increase in the number of pillows he needs to sleep due to difficulty in breathing when lying down flat. The patient also mentioned episodes of nocturia for the past 3 weeks. On examination  he was found to be tachypneic with elevated jugular venous pressure. Auscultation of the chest revealed bibasilar rales and the presence of an S3 heart sound.   This constellation of symptoms suggests a diagnosis of heart failure. Further testing  including EKG  chest imaging  and cardiac biomarker testing  will be beneficial to not only confirm the diagnosis  but also ascertain the severity and probable etiology of heart failure in this patient.

Patient: A 75-year-old African American male  Medical History: He has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with metformin  and hypertension treated with lisinopril. He also has a 30-pack-year smoking history although quit 10 years ago. He has no known cardiac history.  Presenting Symptoms: He presents to the clinic with increasing exertional dyspnea over the course of two months. He has also noticed swelling in his ankles and an increased need to urinate at night. He denies any chest pain but has been feeling fatigued recently.  Based on the medical history and current symptoms  this patient may have developed heart failure. The symptoms of dyspnea  peripheral edema  and nocturia are indicative of congestive heart failure. His significant smoking history  along with the preexisting conditions of hypertension and diabetes  further increase the risk of heart disease. Immediate diagnostic testing (such as labs  ECG  echo) and possible referral to cardiology would likely be warranted.

Patient Profile: A 73-year-old African American male presenting to the clinic.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a known past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (well-controlled with metformin)  hypertension (controlled with lisinopril)  and hyperlipidemia (on atorvastatin therapy). The patient has been a non-smoker and claims moderate alcohol use. He reports that he has been increasingly sedentary due to fatigue.  Symptoms on Presentation: The patient reports a 3-month history of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and ankle swelling. He has also noticed a weight gain of about 10 pounds in the past month  which he attributes to fluid buildup. These indicators suggest a possible decline in cardiac function. He denies chest pain  palpitations  lightheadedness  or syncope. He endorses intermittent bouts of feeling ""an extra heartbeat "" which may suggest arrhythmia  but these episodes are infrequent and without consistent triggers. Physical examination reveals an elevated jugular venous pressure  a laterally displaced apical beat  and peripheral edema.  Potential Diagnosis: Given the symptomatology  the patient's demographics  and the course of his disease  a provisional diagnosis of chronic heart failure (possibly systolic) secondary to his longstanding hypertension or possible underlying coronary artery disease could be reasonable. His diabetes poses additional risk. His described ""extra heartbeat"" sensation could indicate an arrhythmia  but further assessment would be needed. A comprehensive cardiac evaluation  including ECG and echocardiogram  is recommended for more accurate diagnosis and disease staging.

Patient Profile: A 73-year-old African-American male retired construction worker with medical background significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a ten-year history of tobacco use.  Presenting Problem: The patient has been experiencing symptoms consistent with congestive heart failure  characterized by progressively worsening exertional dyspnea  fatigue  and lower extremity edema over the past six weeks. He reports a sudden weight gain of 10 pounds within the recent two weeks. He has developed orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  reporting that he needs to sleep with three pillows to breathe comfortably at night. He has also noticed a decrease in urination frequency. The patient is currently on medication for hypertension and diabetes but he reports missing doses frequently due to forgetfulness. His diet is enriched in sodium with low intake of fruits and vegetables  and he does not engage in regular physical activity.  Relevant Medical History: Past medical records show uncontrolled hypertension and poorly managed diabetes. There is also a documented history of a recent myocardial infarction about two months back. The patient was advised lifestyle modifications including salt and fluid restriction  medication compliance  cessation of smoking  dietary improvements  and inclusion of physical activity  however  none of these have been significantly implemented. He has a family history of heart disease  with his father dying of heart failure at an age of 67.

Patient Profile: An African American female  aged 73  with a problem representation of chronic heart failure.  Medical History: She has a longstanding medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago. She also has a family history of heart disease with her mother having died from a heart attack at the age of 65.  Presenting Symptoms: She presents with generalized fatigue  worsening exertional dyspnea  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and lower extremity swelling over the last 2 weeks. She also reported a recent unintentional weight gain and reduced urine output. Examination revealed elevated jugular venous pressure  bilateral crackles in lower lung fields  and 2+ pitting edema in both lower extremities. Dartmouth Co-op 6-item Chart  a heart failure assessment tool  was used which indicated decreased functional status due to heart failure symptoms. Blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  heart rate 78 beats per minute  and blood glucose level was 160 mg/dL. Electrocardiogram showed left ventricular hypertrophy and chest X-ray showed cardiomegaly and bilateral pulmonary congestion.  Clinical Issue: This is a case of decompensated chronic heart failure in the setting of uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes in an elderly African American woman. She is potentially at a high risk of morbidity and mortality given her age  race  and co-morbid conditions. The primary concern at this point is to manage her heart failure symptoms and control her blood pressure and glucose levels. She might also require examination of heart structure via echocardiography and possibly cardiac catheterization to evaluate her coronary arteries given her family history of heart disease.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes.  Chief Complaint: Rapid weight gain  shortness of breath especially on exertion  increased swelling in the lower extremities and fatigue for past 2 weeks.  History of Present Illness: Patient reports a weight gain of about 10 lbs in last two weeks  more pronounced swelling in both ankles and feet  particularly at the end of the day. He's been experiencing episodes of breathlessness while performing even mild activity like walking short distances. Patient also endorses increased fatigue  interrupting his daily activities  and reduced appetite. He has been compliant with antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications  but reports no significant changes in diet or lifestyle recently.   Family History: Father died of a heart attack at the age of 70. Mother has a history of hypertension and is alive at 87.   Social History: He's a non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  and is retired from a job as school clerk.    Physical Examination: On examination  patient was found to be dyspneic but oriented. He demonstrates pitting edema in both lower extremities  jugular venous distention  cardiac exam revealed a third heart sound (S3)  lungs are clear to auscultation.   Assessment: Given the patient’s older age  presence of risk factors such as hypertension  and diabetes  and the presence of symptomatic fluid overload (as indicated by rapid weight gain  dyspnea on exertion  edema  and an S3)  a determination can be made of decompensated heart failure.   Plan: Admission for diuresis and close monitoring for response to treatment  cardiac biomarkers  chest X-ray  EKG  and consultation with cardiology. Patient education on low sodium diet and monitoring daily weights to report further weight gain.

Patient Profile: A 67-year-old African American male  Medical History: The patient has a longstanding history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia for the past 15 years. He's a past smoker who quit 5 years ago but has a 30-pack year history. Previously  he had adhered to medications and lifestyle modifications  including a low-sodium diet. There is also a family history of heart diseases.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with gradually worsening shortness of breath over the past two weeks  especially with mild exertion or when lying flat. He complains about frequent nighttime awakenings due to breathlessness. He also reports recent onset easy fatigability  reduced exercise tolerance  and noticeable swelling in his ankles and feet. He denies chest pain  lightheadedness  or syncope.   Physical Examination: On physical examination  his BMI is 32  BP is 150/90 mmHg  and pulse is 88 bpm. Cardiovascular examination reveals displaced apex beat and an S3 gallop. Bibasal crackles are audible on lung auscultation. There is bilateral pitting pedal edema.   This is a high-risk patient presenting with signs and symptoms of heart failure  likely due to uncontrolled hypertension and persistent high-risk factors such as diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and obesity.   Given the population prevalence and risk factors  this case is a typical representation of heart failure. The demographic factors have been added taking into account the real-world patient population as chronic heart failure disproportionately affects racial/ethnic minorities  especially African Americans  older adults  and those with comorbid conditions like hypertension and diabetes.

Patient Profile: Maria Hernandez  a 72-year-old Hispanic female  retired teacher.  Relevant Past Medical History: Maria has a history of Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  which have been managed with Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin respectively for the past 15 years. She also has a previous record of ischemic heart disease and suffered a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) 5 years ago.  Presenting Complaints: Over the past 3 months  Maria has noticed increasing breathlessness especially on her nightly walks  difficulty in lying flat due to breathlessness  and occasional waking up from sleep due to severe breathlessness. She has also been experiencing a significant reduction in exercise tolerance  persistent cough  and noticeable unintentional weight gain. She has noticed that her ankles appear puffy at the end of the day.  On Examination: She is overweight with a BMI of 28. She appears mildly distressed due to respiratory discomfort. Her blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  heart rate is 90 bpm  and respiratory rate is 22 bpm. On cardiovascular examination  there are signs of raised jugular venous pressure. Auscultation reveals an audible third heart sound (S3) and basal crepitations are noted on lung examination. Her lower extremities present with bilateral pitting edema.  Based on her past medical history  presenting symptoms  and physical exam findings  Maria is likely suffering from congestive heart failure.

Patient Profile:   A 71-year-old African-American male patient presents with complaints of increasing dyspnea  fatigue  and lower limb edema.   Medical History:   The patient has a known history of hypertension for the past 10 years  Type 2 diabetes for the past 7 years  and ischemic heart disease. He has had two myocardial infarctions  one 5 years ago and the second a year ago  both managed by angioplasty. He was also diagnosed with COPD after a history of chronic smoking.   Presenting symptoms:   Over the past week  he reported experiencing exertional dyspnea  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  bloating  leg swelling  weight gain  and diminished exercise tolerance. These symptoms have worsened in the past two days  with difficulty breathing even when at rest. He has also noticed decreased urine output.  This case presents signs and symptoms consistent with congestive heart failure  likely due to long-standing hypertension  history of coronary artery disease with previous myocardial infarctions  and added co-morbidity of Diabetes and COPD.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson is a 67-year-old African American woman presenting today with chief complaints of increasing dyspnea on exertion  fatigue  and persistently swollen ankles. She was recently diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes and has been managing it with oral hypoglycaemic agents. She is a non-smoker and drinks socially. There is a family history of ischemic cardiomyopathy; her deceased mother was diagnosed with severe heart disease at the age of 75.  On examination  Ms. Johnson is not in acute distress but appears tired. There is bilateral ankle edema. Lung sounds reveal rales halfway up in bilateral lung fields. Heart sounds reveal an S3 gallop. Her blood pressure is at 150/100 mmHg  showing mild hypertension.  Her current symptoms of fatigue  dyspnea on exertion  and lower extremity edema  combined with her personal medical history of diabetes  suggest the possibility of heart failure. Further diagnostic testing  including an ECG and an echocardiogram  are required to confirm this tentative diagnosis of heart failure.

Patient Presentation: A 72-year-old African American male with a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and previous myocardial infarction 3 years ago presents with progressive shortness of breath for the past one week. He reports increased fatigue  orthopnea  and episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He denies chest pain  palpitations  or syncope. He also notes a significant weight gain over the last two weeks. He has a 20-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. He's currently taking oral hypoglycemic agents  beta-blockers  and aspirin as prescribed. His diet is high in salt and he admits occasional non-compliance with his medications. An examination revealed elevated jugular venous pressure  crackles at lung bases  displaced apex beat  and bilateral lower limb edema.   This patient's symptoms and signs are suggestive of decompensated heart failure  possibly secondary to uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  and a past myocardial infarction. The smoking history  diet  and medication non-compliance can be additional contributing factors to his heart failure. Further investigations including echocardiography and laboratory tests will be required to confirm his diagnosis and guide management.

Patient is a 68-year-old African-American male with a known medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and ischemic heart disease  presenting with new-onset heart failure. The patient reports experiencing progressive dyspnea on exertion and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea over the last few weeks. He also mentions having noticeable leg swelling  which worsens by the end of the day. The patient's symptoms have progressively worsened  and he now reports difficulty doing everyday activities due to lack of breath. He denied any chest pain  recent infections  fever  cough  or palpitations. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin  and he has no known drug allergies. He is an ex-smoker and admits to drinking alcohol occasionally. The patient is retired and lives with his spouse.

Patient Profile:   Patient is a 75-year-old African American male  retired steelworker  current smoker with a 50-pack-year history  exhibits non-compliance with hypertensive medications.  Relevant Medical History:   The patient has a known history of systemic hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and congestive heart failure along with a current usage of angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. Given the concerning lack of compliance with antihypertensive medications  the patient has experienced recurrent episodes of hypertension exacerbations over the last decade  culminating in his current systolic dysfunction.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient presents to the clinic with progressive shortness of breath on exertion  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  orthopnea  increased lower extremity edema  and episodes of syncope. He also reports a reduction in exercise capacity  early satiety  bloating  and happens to have gained about 5kg in the past month. On physical examination  there are signs of peripheral and pulmonary congestion and evidence of elevated jugular venous pressure. Echocardiography reveals a significantly reduced ejection fraction.   The above presentation is consistent with decompensated heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. Immediate steps to improve his symptoms  coerce with medication compliance  and the potential need to introduce additional heart failure therapies have been discussed with the patient.

Patient Profile: A 64-year-old African American male  Medical History: Former smoker with a 30-pack year history. He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. Also  the patient has been previously diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD) and had a myocardial infarction (MI) 10 years ago. His family history is positive for heart disease  his father having died of an MI at age 72.  Presenting Symptoms: Patient reports a 4-week history of increasing shortness of breath  particularly noticeable when he lies flat or exerts himself. He also describes generalized fatigue  decreased exercise tolerance  and frequent episodes of nocturia. He notes that he has been awakening at night due to shortness of breath. On further probing  patient admits to a poor appetite and lower leg edema. His diabetes has been poorly controlled over the past few months  with recent HbA1c showing 9.2%.  Physical Examination: On examination  he appears mildly distressed with a respiratory rate of 22 per minute. Cardiac examination revealed an enlarged point of maximal impulse  S3 gallop  and a pansystolic murmur suggesting mitral regurgitation. Auscultation of lungs showed bilateral basal crackles. Lower extremities revealed 2+ peripheral edema up to the level of the shins.  Inference: Considering the patient's medical history of CAD  MI  uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and symptoms including shortness of breath  fatigue  nocturia  and peripheral edema  this patient likely presents with decompensated heart failure.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old African-American male presents with complaints of heart failure.  Medical History:  This patient has a significant past medical history  that includes hypertension for the past 10 years  poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus for 7 years  and chronic kidney disease (Stage 3) diagnosed 5 years ago. He is an ex-smoker  quit 3 years ago  however he had a history of smoking approximately 1-pack per day for 30 years.   Current Presentation: He presents with progressive  generalized weakness  shortness of breath upon exertion  and dyspnea (difficulty breathing) when lying down which forced him to sleep in a semi-upright position for the past couple of weeks. Additionally  he also reports experiencing increasing lower leg edema  weight gain of around 10 pounds over the same period and intermittent nocturia (nighttime urination) during the night. His appetite has been decreased for the same period.   Physical Exam:  On examination  the patient appears distressed with a faint diaphoretic (sweaty) sheen on his forehead. He speaks in short  broken sentences due to breathlessness. His report of dyspnea rating is 7/10. Blood pressure is 165/90 mmHg  heart rate is 78 beats per minute (BPM)  normal rhythm  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Examination shows bilateral pitting pedal edema up to the knees and jugular venous distension suggesting fluid overload. There is also the presence of an S3 gallop rhythm on cardiac auscultation. Lungs reveal crackles at the lung bases bilaterally. Skin turgor suggests overall dehydration despite fluid overload. Other systems are within normal limits.

Patient is a 72-year-old African American male presenting with worsening shortness of breath  fatigue  and persistent cough. He reports increasing difficulty in completing everyday activities and reports new onset of ankle swelling. Medical history reveals type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and a 50-pack-year smoking history. Patient’s family history includes father with myocardial infarction at age 58 and mother with stroke at age 72. Patient reports he has been compliant with all prescribed medications for his underlying health conditions. However  his symptoms have gradually worsened over the past several weeks. Physical exam shows elevated jugular venous pressure  bilateral crackles on lung auscultation  and 3+ pitting edema in both lower extremities. Vital signs: Blood pressure 145/90 mm Hg  Heart rate 98 beats per minute irregular  Respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation 92% on room air.

Patient Profile: A 72-year-old African-American male  Presenting Problem: New onset heart failure  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is also a 10-year smoker  with moderate alcohol use. No known allergies. Family history includes father who died of myocardial infarction at age 74.  Current Symptoms: The patient presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion over the past 2 months  now associated with orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He also reports unintended weight gain of approximately 10 pounds during this period. On examination  his blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate is 88 beats per minute  and respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. Auscultation of his heart reveals an S3 gallop. Evidence of pitting edema in both legs up to the level of the knees is also noted.   Current Medication: Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily  Atorvastatin 20mg nightly.  Given his multiple risk factors (age  race  smoking and family history) and the presenting symptoms  the diagnosis of heart failure is suggested. The patient's hypertension and hyperlipidemia  if inadequately controlled  might have caused substantial damage to his heart over time  possibly leading to this heart failure.   He needs further diagnostic evaluation including chest x-ray  ECG  and echocardiography to confirm the diagnosis and assess the left ventricular function. Treatment adjustments by introducing additional medication and lifestyle modifications would also be recommended based on the results of the further diagnostics.

Patient Profile: Mr. Williams  a 67-year-old African American male retired school teacher  non-smoker.   Presenting Problem: Mr. Williams reports increasing fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion over the past 2 months. He has been experiencing difficulty doing simple household chores and walking short distances which he previously accomplished with ease. He notes swelling in his feet and legs  mentioning that his shoes and socks feel tighter than normal. He also mentions awaking from sleep due to shortness of breath and having to sit up to breathe comfortably.  Medical History: Hypertension for 10 years  well controlled on medication. History of ischemic heart disease  managed conservatively. No history of diabetes or high cholesterol.  Preliminary Assessment: Mr. Williams' symptoms of exertional dyspnea  orthopnea  nocturnal dyspnea  and peripheral edema suggest he may be experiencing congestive heart failure. His history of hypertension and heart disease are both risk factors for this condition. Additional diagnostic evaluations are needed for definitive diagnosis and management.

Patient Representation:  Mr. Davis  a 65-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  presents with symptoms of shortness of breath  edema in lower extremities  and extreme fatigue. He reports that he's been feeling increasingly ""out of breath"" in recent weeks  even while at rest  and has gained 10 pounds within the last month. His medical history also includes smoking  obesity (BMI: 32.5) and a family history of heart disease and stroke. His mother died at the age of 70 from a heart attack. Mr. Davis is currently taking Metformin for his diabetes and Lisinopril for his hypertension. His father  aged 78  is living with heart failure as well. He reports infrequent usage of alcohol and has quit smoking 5 years ago. On examination  he appears dyspneic  with jugular venous distention and bilateral 2+ pitting edema in his lower extremities. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. His symptoms  along with his medical history and physical examination findings strongly suggest possible heart failure.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old African American male  retired truck driver  married  current smoker.  Medical History: There is a 10-year history of poorly controlled hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and moderate obesity. The patient also has a history of prior myocardial infarction two years ago and surgical revascularization  now being managed with low-dose aspirin  Clopidogrel  and a statin.  Presentation: The patient presents with persistent dyspnea on exertion  orthopnea  and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He also reports noticeable weight gain over the past weeks which he attributes to water retention. His wife has also observed him being increasingly fatigued  experiencing difficulty in performing his daily activities. Additionally  he reports occasional  mild chest pain that radiates to his left arm  a rating of 4 on a 10-point pain scale  with no obvious triggers.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  he is found to have a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  BMI of 30  bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities  tachycardia with irregular rhythm  jugular venous distension  and mild crackles on bilateral lung auscultation. His blood glucose level is above the target range.  Given his medical history and current presentation  heart failure appears to be the primary problem. Further studies would be needed to confirm this diagnosis and assess for any potentially reversible causes  such as uncontrolled hypertension and sub-optimally treated ischemic heart disease. An echocardiogram could provide information on his cardiac function and structure. Treating his diabetes and hypertension and encouraging lifestyle changes like exercise  weight loss  low-sodium diet  and smoking cessation would be critical to his care.

Subject is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents with symptoms consistent with advanced heart failure. Onset was gradual over several months  with patient reporting breathlessness  reduced exercise tolerance  frequent nocturnal urination  and dependent edema. Patient has a past medical history notable for hypertension  treated with lisinopril  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with metformin. His family history includes father who died of myocardial infarction at age 75 and mother with type 2 diabetes and hypertension who is still living. Patient is a non-smoker and consumes occasional alcohol. He is a retired engineer who lives with his wife in a suburban community. Recently  he states that his breathlessness and fatigue have become so inhibitive that he's had to stop golfing  a favorite hobby. The patient has seen a noticeable weight gain due to edema and has often woken up short of breath in the middle of the night.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and smoking presents to the emergency department with exertional dyspnea  orthopnea  and swelling in the lower limbs. He reports that his symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past month. His wife has also noticed the patient frequently waking up from sleep with a gasping breath.  Lately  he has been experiencing a decrease in exercise tolerance and gets exhausted after walking a few meters. Past medical history indicates poor blood pressure control and irregular adherence to prescribed antidiabetic medications. The patient denies chest pain or discomfort at present  but reports episodes of sensation of rapid  fluttering heartbeats in the past week.  Family history reveals both his parents had cardiovascular disease. On physical examination  he looks dyspneic and is found to have jugular venous distention  bilateral rales in the lungs and 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities up to the level of the knees. Blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg  heart rate 105/min sinus tachycardia  respirations 20/min  oxygen saturation 95% on room air.  This case features a patient presenting symptoms typically associated with heart failure - the exertional dyspnea  orthopnea  nocturnal paroxysmal dyspnea  lower limb edema and the presence of jugular venous distension are classic signs. His demographic factors - age  race  male gender - all align with data indicating an elevated risk for heart failure. His history of poorly managed hypertension and diabetes  smoking habit  and family history are additional risk factors that likely contributed to the development of his condition.

Patient Profile: A 62-year-old African American male.  Presenting Complaint: Shortness of breath  swelling in the legs  and tiredness for 3 weeks.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both conditions have been managed with medications for the past 8 years. Patient has a 30-pack year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. Patient also admits non-compliance with his low-salt diet and missed doses of his anti-hypertensive medications in the past week. There is no known history of previous cardiac disease.   Symptoms: The patient reports worsening shortness of breath  particularly when lying down  and often wakes him up in the middle of the night. He also reports noticing increased swelling in both legs and feet over the past week. Despite adequate sleep  the patient has been persistently feeling tired. He also mentions a recent unintentional weight gain of 4-5 kilograms.   Physical Examination: On examination  the patient has an elevated heart rate  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  and an increased respiratory rate. Palpation reveals an elevated jugular venous pressure. Auscultation reveals bibasilar crackles in lungs and a third heart sound (S3 gallop). Inspection reveals bilateral lower limb edema. No chest pain reported during the examination.  Clinical Impression: The patient's signs  symptoms  and history are consistent with heart failure. His risk factors include poorly controlled hypertension  type 2 diabetes  history of smoking  and dietary non-compliance.

Patient Initials: J.B.  Age: 75 years Sex: Male Race: Non-Hispanic White  Chief Complaint: Shortness of breath and fatigue  History of Present Illness:  75-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 6 week history of gradually worsening shortness of breath  fatigue  and increased swelling in his legs and ankles. The shortness of breath is particularly prominent when patient is lying flat and improves with sitting upright. Patient also reports recent unintentional weight gain.  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension  - Prior myocardial infarction 5 years ago - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Family History:  - Father died of Myocardial Infarction at age 70 - Brother with heart failure   Social History:  - Former smoker; quit 10 years ago - Occasional alcohol use - Sedentary lifestyle   Physical Examination: General: Alert and oriented  seems uncomfortable  in mild distress  Respiratory: Rapid shallow breathing  bilateral basal crackles  Cardiovascular: Elevated jugular venous pulse  displaced apex beat  presence of S3 gallop  Abdominal: Abdominal distention  Lower Extremities: 2+ pitting edema up to the mid-shin   These findings are consistent with congestive heart failure  likely secondary to his long standing hypertension and previous myocardial infarction. The patient’s sedentary lifestyle and history of smoking also place him at a higher risk for developing heart failure.

Patient Profile: Mr. Alfred Johnson  an 65-year-old African-American male.  Presenting Complaint: Shortness of breath  fatigue and swelling in the legs  ankles  and feet.  Past Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension and Type II diabetes approximately ten years ago  currently managed through medication and dietary modifications. Nonsmoker. His father passed away due to heart disease in his early 70s.  Symptoms: Mr. Johnson has been experiencing increasing fatigue even with minimal physical exertion  shortness of breath  especially when lying flat  and swollen lower extremities over the past three weeks. He reported a gain weight of around 5 pounds within this period. He also mentioned waking up in the middle of the night feeling breathless and needing more pillows to sleep comfortably.  Physical Examination Findings: Upon physical examination  there was evidence of raised jugular venous pressure  mild pulmonary congestion  and lower extremity edema. Blood pressure is mildly elevated at 140/90 mmHg  heart rate regular at 80 bpm.  Working Diagnosis: Symptoms and physical examination findings are indicative of congestive heart failure in Mr. Johnson. His risk factors include age  ethnicity  hypertension  Type II diabetes  and family history of heart disease. Further diagnostic testing  including chest radiography  echocardiogram  and blood tests  are needed to confirm and evaluate the severity of heart failure.

Patient Description: A 65-year-old African-American male  married  retired auto mechanic  and current smoker  presenting with new-onset dyspnea and fatigue.  Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago; he adheres to medication but doesn't maintain a rigid control on diet. He had a myocardial infarction two years ago and was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention to the right coronary artery. He has no known drug allergies.  Presentation: Over the past two weeks  the patient has reported worsening dyspnea on exertion  needing to rest after walking a mere half-block. He also mentioned experiences of orthopnea  needing three pillows to sleep  compared to his usual one  and nocturnal dyspnea wakening him from sleep. There were no symptoms of chest pain  diaphoresis  or palpitations. He's also felt an overwhelming sense of fatigue and noticed a weight gain of approximately 10 lbs in the past month. On examination  he has a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 90 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 bpm  and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. He reveals bibasilar rales on lung auscultation  distended jugular veins  and mild pitting edema on both lower extremities.  Problem: This constellation of symptoms and clinical findings is consistent with a likely diagnosis of decompensated systolic heart failure with possible fluid overload or chronic heart failure exacerbation  potentially secondary to underlying ischemic heart disease  hypertension or diabetes.

Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a documented history of type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and left ventricular hypertrophy. He was diagnosed with coronary artery disease last year for which he was treated via a percutaneous coronary intervention. He has been compliant to his medications which include a combination of ACE inhibitors  metformin  and statins. He also has a 40-pack year history of smoking  which he quit 10 years ago.   Current Presentation:  The patient has been suffering from progressive exertional dyspnea  orthopnea  and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea over the past month. Over the past week  he has developed swelling in his legs and a noted increase in abdominal girth with associated weight gain  despite a diminishing appetite. He additionally reports a new onset of fatigue  even at rest  and reports waking up at night gasping for breath.  Preliminary Diagnosis: Causal linkage and symptoms suggest acute decompensated heart failure secondary to long-standing hypertension and possibly ischemic heart disease. However  further targeted diagnostic tests are needed for confirmatory diagnosis and to guide the therapeutic decision-making process. The new onset of symptoms and their rapid progression is concerning and warrants immediate medical attention.

Patient Profile:   A 70-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  diabetes  and previous myocardial infarction (10 years ago).  Chief Complaint: He presents with increasing shortness of breath  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  inability to lie flat  and fatigue.  History of Present Illness: The patient has been experiencing symptoms of shortness of breath and orthopnea for the previous two weeks. These symptoms initially occurred with physical exertion but have now been bothering him even at rest over the last two days. He reports of waking up breathless from sleep and needing to sit up for relief. He also reports of generalized fatigue and reduced ability to perform daily activities. He denies any chest pain  palpitations  light-headedness  or loss of consciousness.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known past history of hypertension and diabetes  both well controlled with medications. He had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago for which he underwent successful intervention but has been lax in cardiac follow-ups in recent years.  Review of Systems: The patient also admits to occasional dry cough and swollen ankles. He denies recent weight change  fevers  chills  night sweats  gastrointestinal symptoms  or urinary symptoms.   Based on this presentation  the most likely medical problem is worsening congestive heart failure. Further diagnostics including labs  electrocardiogram  echocardiogram  and potentially cardiac catheterization will be needed for further evaluation and management optimization.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male with a medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  chronic kidney disease  and a 30-pack year smoking history  presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion over the past month. He reports increasing fatigue  orthopnea  and symptoms of peripheral edema including swelling around his ankles and feet. He also notes weight gain of 10 pounds in the past 2 weeks. He has a family history of heart disease  with his father passing away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 70.   The patient's physical examination is noticeable for bilateral crackles in the lung bases  jugular venous distension  and pitting edema in both lower extremities. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/90 mmHg and heart rhythm was irregularly irregular on auscultation.  Mr. Rodriguez's symptom profile of dyspnea  orthopnea  peripheral edema  weight gain  and observed bi-basilar crackles  jugular venous distention  and pitting edema are highly suggestive of congestive heart failure. His long-standing history of smoking  hypertension  and diabetes  in addition to his family history of heart disease  further elevate his risk for developing heart failure.

Patient Profile: Mr. Thompson  an 65-year-old African American male  retired construction worker  Presenting Problem: He presents at the clinic with a chief complaint of increasing shortness of breath over the past month  particularly when engaging in physical activities  such as walking for more than several minutes or climbing stairs  that were previously not problematic. He expresses that these activities have been causing him to tire quickly and he often wakes up gasping for breath at night.  Relevant Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a history of hypertension for 15 years and was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes 10 years ago. His other relevant past medical history includes an acute myocardial infarction 5 years ago. He has been moderately compliant to his prescribed medications including anti-hypertensives and oral hypoglycemic agents.   Relevant Symptoms: In addition to shortness of breath and fatigue  Mr. Thompson has been experiencing frequent dry cough  unintentional weight gain  and notable swelling in his feet and ankles. He also reports occasional chest discomfort and palpitations.  Summary: Mr. Thompson is a 65-year old African American male with a medical history notable for hypertension  type 2 diabetes and an acute myocardial infarction  presenting with chronic exertional dyspnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  orthopnea  cough  fatigue  pedal edema  weight gain  and occasional chest discomfort  suggestive of congestive heart failure.

Patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presents with symptoms of progressive shortness of breath  swollen legs  and general fatigue. His medical history features controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. However  he has been non-compliant with his medications over several months. He has a 30-year history of smoking  with cessation 10 years ago. His family history is notable for a father who had a myocardial infarction in his late 60s. On examination  there is notable jugular venous distension  a S3 heart sound with rales in the bilateral lower lung fields  and 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities. The patient's symptoms suggest heart failure  likely related to a combination of non-compliance to hypertensive and diabetic medications  a long history of smoking  and possible genetic predisposition.

Patient: 73-year-old African American male   Chief Complaint: Shortness of breath  fatigue  and swelling in the legs and stomach   History of Present Illness: Patient presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion and increasing fatigue over the past 6 months. He has experienced orthopnea and nocturnal paroxysmal dyspnea over the past month. The patient reports chemosis and edema of lower extremities that has gotten worse over the last week.   Past Medical History: History of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and ischemic heart disease. No history of smoking or alcohol use. Patient had a myocardial infarction 7 years ago.   Family History: Father had heart disease and died at age 66. Two siblings also diagnosed with hypertension.   Review of Systems: Negative for fever  cough  chest pain. Positive for weight gain over the past months  decreased appetite and nausea.  Physical Examination: BP 150/90 mmHg  Pulse 96 bpm and irregularly irregular  Respiratory rate 18/min   Oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Examination notable for jugular venous distension  hepatomegaly  bilateral crackles on lung bases  3+ pitting edema lower extremities bilaterally.  Assessment: Based on the clinical symptoms and the significant past medical history  the patient appears to be experiencing decompensated congestive heart failure.   Plan: Further evaluation with laboratory tests including CBC  BMP  BNP  LFTs  and TSH. Cardiac imaging with an echocardiogram will be essential to analyze cardiac function. Referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management. Lifestyle modifications and likely adjustments to current medications will also be necessary.

Patient is a 76-year-old African American male presented with acute episodes of dyspnea  orthopnea  and lower limb edema. The patient has a known history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and chronic kidney disease. He also has a 20-year pack smoking history. Family history revealed his father suffered from congestive heart failure. On physical examination  he was tachycardic  had bilateral rales in lower lobes  jugular venous distention  and edema in lower limbs. The patient confirms adherence to hypertensive and diabetic medications on the regular basis. Recent notable change in weight was reported  roughly 20 pounds gain in the last month. His diminished exercise tolerance and increased episodes of nocturia suggest a potential exacerbation of heart failure symptoms.

Patient Profile: A 72-year-old African American man  retired construction worker  residing in urban area  with history of Type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He is a former smoker  with a 30-pack year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He has a known family history of heart disease  with his mother surviving a myocardial infarction at a relatively young age.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient was experiencing increasing shortness of breath over the past month  especially during routine activities like walking up a flight of stairs. This was accompanied by persistent cough  unusual tiredness and noticeable swelling in the ankles  feet  legs  abdomen  and sometimes  around the eyes. The patient also reported waking up in the middle of the night feeling breathless  a symptom known as paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and rapid weight gain in the past few weeks.  Medical History: This patient was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes 10 years ago and has been managing it with Metformin. He has also been diagnosed with controlled hypertension  being managed on a regimen of Amlodipine for the past 12 years. His last recorded blood pressure in a primary care visit 3 months prior was 128/82 mmHg. He has a known history of high LDL cholesterol level controlled with Statins. He has no known drug allergies.  Given these parameters  this patient's presentation suggests advanced heart failure  likely given his history of diabetes  hypertension  and a genetic predisposition to cardiovascular disease. The sudden increase in severity of symptoms indicates a likely decompensated heart failure. A comprehensive cardiac evaluation is warranted.

Patient: 72-year-old African American male  Medical History: The patient is a retired steelworker with a history of hypertension and Type II diabetes which have been relatively well controlled with medication. He has also been a heavy smoker for the past 45 years. There is also a history of coronary artery disease in the family.  Presenting Symptoms: Over the past month  the patient has been experiencing progressive shortness of breath  particularly when lying flat (orthopnea) and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (sudden nighttime shortness of breath). The patient also reports new-onset swelling in both ankles  fatigue  and weight gain of approximately 5 lbs in the past week. On more intense questioning  the patient also describes occasional bouts of chest pain or discomfort  most often occurring with activity or stress  and relieved with rest (angina). The patient's blood pressure is slightly elevated  and on physical examination  there are findings suggestive of fluid overload  including jugular venous distention (JVD) and pitting edema.

Patient Profile: African American female  age 68  Medical History: The patient has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. She has been smoking a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years and reports a family history of heart-related diseases.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with symptoms that have progressively worsened over the past six months. She reports experiencing excessive tiredness  shortness of breath after minor physical exertion  persistent cough or wheezing  increased heart rate  swelling in the legs  ankles and feet  and rapid weight gain due to fluid retention.  Problem Representation: A 68-year-old African American female with a past medical history significant for Diabetes Type II  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and smoking  who presents with symptoms consistent with worsening heart failure. The patient's multi-faceted risk factors in addition to her specific symptoms necessitate immediate evaluation and intervention to manage her current health status and mitigate further deterioration of her condition.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old African-American male  Medical History: Has a diagnosed condition of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Ex-smoker who quit 20 years ago but had a 20 pack/year history. Adherence to medication is generally good but occasionally misses doses due to forgetfulness. Family history of heart disease with the father having died from a heart attack at age 62.  Presenting Complaint: Over the past month  the patient has been experiencing increasing shortness of breath  particularly during exertion such as when climbing stairs. Has noticed swelling of his ankles and feet  particularly by the end of the day. Also complains of trouble sleeping due to breathlessness  needing to prop himself up on several pillows. Reports a recent mild  unintentional weight gain and feeling generally fatigued and weak during the day.  On examination: JVP elevated  bilateral pitting edema in the lower limbs seen. S3 heart sounds could be appreciated on cardiac auscultation. Chest auscultation revealed rales in the lower lobes of the lung. Blood pressure measured was 145/95 mmHg.  Preliminary Diagnosis: These symptoms are consistent with congestive heart failure  possibly related to patient's long-term hypertension and history of smoking. Further diagnostic tests  like ECG and echocardiogram  would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis  assess the severity  and guide the treatment plan.

Patient: African American male  aged 65.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a long-standing history of hypertension for 15 years  which is inadequately controlled despite being on multiple antihypertensive medications. His other past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) for 10 years and moderate chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to diabetic nephropathy. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially.  Relevant Symptoms: For the past two weeks  the patient has experienced progressive dyspnea with minimal exertion and intermittent episodes of orthopnea. He also noted lower extremity swelling and noticed that he has gained about 10 pounds of weight within these two weeks. Moreover  he reports recent onset of palpitations and has experienced a loss in appetite accompanied by nausea.  On physical examination  the patient is seen to have a displaced apex beat with a gallop rhythm on cardiac auscultation. His jugular venous pressure is elevated and there are bilateral crackles at the base of the lungs. Lower extremities show pitting edema up to the level of the knees.  These symptoms and signs are suggestive of congestive heart failure  requiring further evaluation including chest x-ray  EKG  and echocardiogram to assess the severity of the heart failure  and to evaluate the ejection fraction and valvular functions. The symptom progression  combined with his medical history  put him at high risk for heart failure.

Patient: 70-year-old African American male.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with symptoms of heart failure  including shortness of breath  fatigue  swelling in legs  rapid weight gain due to fluid retention  and frequent nighttime urination.  Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. He is a former 20 pack-year smoker but quit two years age. His family history is significant for his father having myocardial infarction at age 60.  Background: The patient lives with his wife in an urban community. Due to his symptom progression  he is limited to light housework and grocery shopping. Prior to his symptoms  he was active in his church community and maintained a small home garden.  Summary: 70-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for hypertension  diabetes  and smoking  now presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with heart failure. His symptoms appear to be impacting his lifestyle and daily activities. His family history of cardiac issues may be a contributing factor. The combination of an ageing demographic  previous health complications  and an ethnic predisposition further complicates his present condition.

Problem Representation:  Patient Name: XXX  Gender: Male  Age: 70 years  Race: African American   Presenting Complaint: Difficulty in breathing  decreased exercise tolerance and swelling in the lower limbs.  Medical History: The patient has a known history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension for the past 15 years. He also has a history of myocardial infarction (heart attack) 3 years ago and was treated with stents.  Medication History: The patient is on Metformin for Diabetes  Lisinopril and Amlodipine for Hypertension.  Family History: Father suffered from heart disease and diabetes. Mother had hypertension.  Social History: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol intake  retired automobile worker.  Examination Findings: Upon examination  the patient appears distressed and dyspnoic. Blood pressure is 155/95mmHg  heart rate - 80bpm  respiratory rate - 22 breaths/min. Cardiac examination reveals an S3 gallop  JVP is elevated indicating increased venous pressure  bilateral pitting edema is notable in the lower limbs indicating fluid overload  and there are bilateral rales/crackles at the bases of the lungs on auscultation indicating fluid accumulation within the lungs (pulmonary congestion).  Diagnosis: Given the patient's presentation and medical history  a working diagnosis of congestive heart failure exacerbation is made. The etiology is likely due to poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes leading to cardiomyopathy  and previous myocardial infarction contributing to decreased heart function  causing an inability of the heart to pump blood properly  leading to fluid back up in body  as evidenced by increased venous pressure (raised JVP  leg edema) and lungs (pulmonary congestion/edema).

Patient Presentation: 78-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia  presents with symptoms of progressive dyspnea on exertion  orthopnea  and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea over the past six weeks. The patient also reports intermittent episodes of lower limb edema and unexplained weight gain. The patient is non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He is compliant to amlodipine  metformin and atorvastatin as part of his chronic disease management. No history of angina or any previous cardiac disease. Family history reveals father had suffered from heart disease. No known allergies.   This patient's chief complaints  associated conditions  and physical findings suggest a differential diagnosis including congestive heart failure. Further diagnostic workup is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the severity of disease in order to institute appropriate therapeutic measures.

Patient Presentation: Mr. A  a 72-year-old African American male  presents with a chief complaint of increasing shortness of breath  persistent coughing during the night and lower extremity swelling  which have progressively worsened over the past two weeks.   Medical History: Mr. A has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He is an ex-smoker with a 20-pack year history but quit smoking 10 years ago. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. His medications include metformin  losartan  and atorvastatin.   Physical Examination: On examination  he has a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  a pulse rate of 85 beats/minute  and respiration rate of 22 breaths/minute. His oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. He is afebrile. He appears mildly distressed due to dyspnea. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rhythm  an S3 gallop  and no murmurs. Chest examination reveals fine crackles at the base of both lungs. Lower extremity examination shows 2+ pitting edema.   Summary: This is a case of a 72-year-old African American male with a history of diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presenting with symptoms suggestive of heart failure such as worsening dyspnea  nocturnal cough  and pedal edema. In light of his age  race  personal medical history  and family history of heart disease  these findings are indicative of likely congestive heart failure.

Patient Profile:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired warehouse worker  widowed  and living alone.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a 15 year history of hypertension  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 7 years. He also has a 40 year pack history of smoking (2 packs/day) but quit 5 years ago. He is currently taking medication for both conditions: metformin for diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension. There's no documented history of any heart disease in his direct family lineage.   Presenting Symptoms:  The patient presents with a one-month history of increasing shortness of breath upon exertion and two weeks of orthopnea. He reports gaining 10 pounds in the past two weeks despite poor appetite and feeling generally unwell. He experiences occasional bouts of dry cough  particularly at night and feels a persistent fatigue. The patient also reports increasing ankle swelling over the same period. No chest pain  palpitations or syncope were reported.

Patient Profile: 72-year-old African-American male.  Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and is a former smoker (30-pack-year history  quit 15 years ago). He also had an ischemic stroke 3 years ago with residual mild left-sided weakness. The patient's medications include Lisinopril  Aspirin  Metformin  and Atorvastatin.  Presenting Symptoms: At his physician's office  the patient reports a 2-month history of increasing shortness of breath with minor exertion and while lying flat in bed  needing to prop up with several pillows to sleep. He also reports intermittent feeling of excessive tiredness  increased waist size despite not gaining weight  loss of appetite with mild nausea  and swelling in his feet and ankles worsening through the day. He denies any chest pain  palpitation  or dizziness.  Physical Examination: Patient is afebrile  blood pressure of 145/95 mmHg  heart rate of 90 bpm  respiratory rate of 20 per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals an S3 gallop and bilateral basal lung crackles on auscultation. Abdominal examination shows hepatomegaly. Lower extremities exhibit 2+ pitting edema.  Based on the history and physical examination findings  the patient is suspected to have congestive heart failure secondary to hypertensive heart disease and potentially diabetic cardiomyopathy. Further diagnostic tests  including blood tests and echocardiography  are warranted to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the disease.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 20-year pack history of smoking presents with progressive shortness of breath over the last two weeks. The patient also reports orthopnea  waking up at night with shortness of breath  and exertional fatigue. On physical examination  he demonstrates an elevated jugular venous pressure  bilateral pitting edema in the lower extremities  and crackles in the lung bases bilaterally. His EKG shows left ventricular hypertrophy and chest x-ray confirms pulmonary edema. This constellation of findings suggests decompensated heart failure. His last normal ejection fraction as per a previous echocardiogram one year ago was 55%.

Patient is a 73 year old Caucasian male  with a history of moderate hypertension  controlled with medication  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past three weeks  increased fatigue  unintentional weight gain of about 7 kilograms  and swelling of his ankles and feet.  He reports he has been increasingly finding it difficult to carry out his usual daily activities due to breathlessness and rapid fatigue  needing to rest more often. His sleep has been disturbed by recurrent nocturnal dyspnea and he routinely has to use several extra pillows to sleep comfortably at night. He has also noticed a marked decrease in his urine output.  No history of similar episodes in the past  no history of any cardiac interventions or surgeries  no history of rheumatic fever or familial heart failure. His daily routine is fairly sedentary with minimal physical activities. He has been adhering to his medication regimen for hypertension and diabetes but admits to occasionally indulging in a high-sodium diet. He is a nonsmoker and does not drink alcohol.  His vital signs on presentation are as follows: BP - 145/90 mmHg  HR - 95 bpm  RR - 23/min  SpO2 - 92% on room air  and temperature - 36.6℃. Physical exam reveals bilateral ankle edema  jugular venous distention  and a displaced apical pulse suggestive of cardiomegaly. There are also audible bilateral rales on lung auscultation and a third heart sound (S3). Rest of physical examination unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:   Patient is an 82-year-old African American male with a past medical history of coronary artery disease (CAD)  hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 40-pack years smoking history who presents with a 3-day history of increasing fatigue  dyspnea on minimal exertion  and lower extremity edema.   History of present illness:   The patient reports his symptoms have gradually worsened over the past 3 days. He has dyspnea on exertion  with inability to walk more than a few steps before becoming short of breath. He denies chest pain or palpitations  but endorses fatigue and increasing frequency of night-time urination.   Physical exam:  On examination  the patient is found to be dyspneic at rest. He appears fatigued  with bibasilar rales on lung auscultation and evident 2+ bilateral lower extremity pitting edema up to the mid-calf. His BMI is 29 with a blood pressure of 165/95 mmHg  pulse at 92 bpm  and SpO2 of 90% on room air.  Assessment:  Given this patient’s age  race  significant cardiac history  clinical symptoms and physical exam findings  he is likely presenting with an acute exacerbation of heart failure. His shortness of breath  fatigue  and signs of fluid overload (edema  rales  increased nocturia) are consistent with this diagnosis. His hypertension is likely contributing to his current exacerbation. Appropriate further investigation includes EKG  chest x-ray  and B-type natriuretic peptide level to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson  a 75-year-old African-American male.  Relevant Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a significant medical history of type II diabetes mellitus (controlled with metformin for the past 5 years)  hypertension (currently on Lisinopril)  and hyperlipidemia (treated with atorvastatin). He had a previous myocardial infarction approximately 10 years ago  and he has a 30-pack year smoking history  although he quit smoking after his heart attack.  Current Presentation: The patient presents with worsening shortness of breath on exertion that has been gradually worsening over the past two weeks  often awakening him at night causing him to sleep upright. The patient also reports feeling fatigue  rapid weight gain of seven pounds in one week  and swelling in his legs and ankles. He denies chest pain  but he mentions that he has noticed a decreased urine output.  On examination  rales are noted on auscultation of his lungs. His heart rate is regular  but a S3 is detected suggesting heart failure. His extremities show 2+ pitting edema bilaterally up to his mid-calf. His oxygen saturation on room air is at an average of 92%.  In summary  the patient is a 75-year-old African-American male with a history of diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and previous myocardial infarction who presents with symptoms of worsening exertional dyspnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  orthopnea  fatigue  weight gain  bilateral leg edema  and decreased urine output  all strongly suggestive of decompensated heart failure.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old African American male  Mr. Jackson  Medical History: Mr. Jackson is a retired construction worker with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type-2 diabetes  and a 20-pack year smoking history  which he quit 5 years ago. He also has a family history of heart disease with his father dying from a heart attack at the age of 72.  Presenting Issue: Mr. Jackson presents with complaints of progressive shortness of breath on exertion over the past month  associated with fatigue  persistent dry cough  and episodes of rapid heart rate. He also reports swelling in his ankles and feet consistently worsening through the day  relieved somewhat with elevation. He mentions a decrease in his appetite and a recent unintentional weight gain of 10 pounds in the past two months.   Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. Jackson is obese (BMI of 32) and appears breathless after minimal exertion. His heart rate is 100 bpm  blood pressure 170/90mmHg  and he has bilateral pitting edema in lower extremities. His lung examination reveals rales at the lung bases. Heart sounds are noted to have a S3 gallop.   Based on his symptoms and physical findings  Mr. Jackson is exhibiting signs consistent with congestive heart failure. Further diagnostic tests are required to confirm the diagnosis and establish the severity of the condition. His medical history suggests multiple risk factors for heart disease  including hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and tobacco use.

Patient Presentation: A 70-year-old African American male with a past medical history notable for untreated hypertension  type 2 diabetes and a 30-year smoking history presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past two months  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  orthopnea  and fatigue. He reports noticing some ankle swelling and intermittently waking up in the middle of the night feeling breathless. The patient also experienced unexplained weight gain over the last 3 weeks. He denies chest pain  palpitations  lightheadedness  or syncope. Physical examination reveals an elevated jugular venous pressure  bilateral rales at lower lung fields  S3 gallop  and pitting edema in lower extremities.

Patient Representation:  Ms. A  a 68-year-old African-American female  with a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past ten years  presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of progressive shortness of breath on exertion  fatigue  and lower limb edema over a period of two months. She also reports waking up from sleep with breathlessness and needing two pillows for relief  suggestive of Orthopnea. She has been adherent to her antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications  but her blood pressure and blood glucose levels have been poorly controlled. She denies chest pain  palpitations  or syncope. She is a non-smoker and abstains from alcohol. Family history is significant for heart disease  both parents succumbing to it in their late sixties. On physical examination  she is obese with a BMI of 32. She appears dyspneic  with bilateral pitting edema of both legs  elevated jugular venous pressure  and crackles on lung base auscultation indicative of pulmonary congestion. Her blood pressure is 148/98 mmHg  pulse rate is 98 bpm  irregular  and respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min. Initial assessment points towards the possibility of congestive heart failure  necessitating further diagnostic testing and management.

Patient Information: Mr. John Green  a 65-year-old African-American male  retired lawyer.  Medical History: Mr. Green has a documented history of poorly controlled hypertension for the past 10 years  being non-compliant with his medications occasionally. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago and is currently on oral hypoglycemic agents. He is also a former smoker  quitting about 2 years ago (20 pack-years)  and occasionally consumes alcohol on social occasions.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Green came to the emergency room complaining of progressive shortness of breath especially on lying down  along with fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance over the past few weeks. He reported a weight gain of around 7 pounds over the past month. The shortness of breath was associated with a non-productive cough and he had noticed some swelling in his ankles as well.  Clinical Examination: He appeared dyspneic at rest. His vital signs showed a blood pressure of 155/95 mmHg  heart rate of 102 bpm  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed elevated jugular venous pressure  an S3 gallop  and distant heart sounds. Chest auscultation disclosed bibasilar rales suggestive of pulmonary edema. Lower limb examination found pitting edema along with cool extremities  indicative of poor peripheral perfusion.  Provisional Diagnosis: Congestive heart failure secondary to long-standing hypertension and diabetes with possible ischemic heart disease.

Patient Overview: 66-year-old African American female.  Past Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus managed through medications. No known allergies.  Presenting Complaints: Over the last month  she has reported gradual onset of exertional dyspnea  non-productive cough and fatigue. Significant gain in weight over the last two weeks.  Physical Examination: Notable jughular venous distention  bibasilar rales on chest auscultation and pitting edema at the lower extremities. Elevated BP at 160/95 mmHg  resting heart rate at 102 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 90% on room air.  Preliminary Conclusion: The patient's symptoms suggest a decompensation of heart failure  possibly exacerbated by poorly controlled hypertension. Her demographics  including age  race  and pre-existing conditions of hypertension and diabetes are consistent with research showing higher risk for heart failure. Further diagnostic tests including echocardiography  chest x-ray  and oblique heart examination to evaluate heart size  pulmonary congestion  and lung disease are necessary. Clinical management would involve optimizing her hypertension and diabetes control  and possibly introducing diuretics to manage her symptoms.

Patient Information: A 66-year-old African American male  lifelong nonsmoker  resident of a suburban community  married  and retired industrial worker.  Medical History: The patient has a significant past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and dyslipidemia. He is currently on metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. The patient's mother  now deceased  was diagnosed with congestive heart failure at age 75.  Presenting Problem: The patient was brought in with complaints of progressive dyspnea on exertion  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  and significant lower limb edema for the past two to three weeks. He has also reported recent weight gain. Over the past two days  he has noted a decrease in urination.  Physical Examination: Physical examination reveals jugular venous distention  bilateral rales in the lung bases  an S3 gallop on cardiac auscultation  and significant bilateral lower limb pitting edema. The heart rate is irregular  and blood pressure is elevated.  Clinical Impressions: The clinical findings are consistent with congestive heart failure  likely stemming from the patient's history of uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes  which may have led to left ventricular hypertrophy and subsequent heart failure. The irregular heart rate may also suggest the onset of atrial fibrillation. Urgent echocardiography  chest X-ray  and lab tests including complete blood count  renal function  hepatic function  and NT-proBNP were recommended to support the diagnosis and determine the severity of heart failure. The patient would then be managed accordingly with medications and lifestyle modifications.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  1. Name: H. Thomas 2. Age: 68  3. Sex: Male  4. Race: Caucasian  5. Occupation: Retired teacher 6. Residence: Urban  7. Marital Status: Widower  Presenting Concern:  Mr. Thomas presented with concerns about recent weight gains  excessive tiredness  and periodic difficulty breathing  especially at night. He mentioned his legs and ankles have been swelling more often too.   Past Medical History:  1) Hypertension - Diagnosed 10 years ago  controlled with medication (Amlodipine 5mg/daily). 2) Type II Diabetes Mellitus - Diagnosed 8 years ago  controlled with oral anti-diabetic medication (Metformin 500mg twice daily). 3) Myocardial Infarction - 5 years ago  managed with lifestyle changes  and Aspirin. 4) Dyslipidemia - Diagnosed 7 years ago  treated with Atorvastatin  5) Anxiety Disorder - Managed with cognitive-behavioral therapy and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI).  Family History:  Mr. Thomas's father died at 74 from a stroke and his mother at 81 due to breast cancer. He has one younger brother diagonsed with coronary artery disease at the age of 60.  Lifestyle:  Mr. Thomas is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He does not exercise regularly. His diet is mostly plant-based with some fish and chicken. He lives alone and manages his basic daily chores independently.  This patient profile fits the typical demographic representation  as found in literature  of an individual more likely to develop heart failure  particularly due to factors such as age  gender  the presence of hypertension and diabetes  previous heart ailment (myocardial infarction)  and family history of cardiovascular diseases.  References:  1. Roger VL. Epidemiology of heart failure. Circulation research. 2013 Aug 30;113(6):646-59. 2. Bui AL  Horwich TB  Fonarow GC. Epidemiology and risk profile of heart failure. Nature Reviews Cardiology. 2011 Jan;8(1):30-41.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Age: 75 years old - Gender: Male - Race: White - Occupation: Retired  former office worker - Residence: Lives in a suburban residential area - Marital status: Married. - Family history: Father and older brother both died of heart disease.  Presenting Complaint: He is presenting with worsening shortness of breath  fatigue  edema in lower extremities  and common symptoms of heart failure.  Medical History: 1.
