Her family history reveals that her mother died of a stroke at 70 and her father passed away from heart disease at 72. She has been a non-smoker all her life and consumes alcohol socially. Her BMI also falls under the category of obesity.  Key Complaints:  Ms. Rodriguez reports experiencing increasing shortness of breath on exertion for the past few weeks. She has also noticed edema(ankle swelling)  especially towards the end of the day. She mentions feeling unusually tired and fatigued  even upon minimal physical activity. Additional complaints include rapid weight gain over a short period and frequent nocturnal urination. Recently  she has experienced occasional bouts of dizziness and rapid heartbeat. Her symptoms are causing concern and have motivated her to seek medical attention.  Notes:  Considering current U.S. racial/ethnic population composition  in which Hispanic populations are drastically increasing  this case encourages students to explore social determinants of health in the context of heart failure. Studies have shown that individuals from minority ethnic groups  particularly African American and Hispanic individuals  have higher prevalence and mortality from heart failure than their Caucasian counterparts. This case will provide students an opportunity to explore potential reasons for this disparity and will encourage a comprehensive approach to patient care. The established relationship between heart failure  diabetes  and hypertension makes Ms. Rodriguez's case clinically relevant and representative.

Case Report: Congestive Heart Failure  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. James Rodriguez Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Ethnicity: Hispanic  Living Situation: Lives with wife in a suburban area  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension – Diagnosed 15 years ago  not well-controlled 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus – Diagnosed 10 years ago  under control 3. Hyperlipidemia – Diagnosed 8 years ago  under treatment 4. Smoker – 20 cigarettes a day for the past 30 years 5. Excessive alcohol consumption – stopped 3 years ago 6. No known allergies  Family History: Father had Cardiovascular disease. He passed away at the age of 68 due to a heart attack. Mother  88 years old  is alive with hypertension and type II diabetes.  Key Complaints: 1. Progressive shortness of breath over the past 3 months  especially while exerting and at night 2. Swelling of feet and abdomen for the past month 3. Fatigue and slight weight gain  despite not eating much 4. Occasional chest pain over the past 2 weeks  Sociocultural Factors:  Mr. Rodriguez is a Spanish speaker  although he understands basic English. He relies heavily on his wife  who speaks fluent English  to communicate with health care professionals. As a retired construction worker  he has limited access to health care due to restrictive insurance conditions. However  he is an active member in his local community church.  Please note: The prevalence of heart failure is higher in older males  Hispanics  and those with a history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and cardiovascular disease. The case presents a patient who is both typical of those diagnosed with heart failure and includes common associated conditions. This is intended to provide students with a realistic scenario to develop their diagnostic and management skills.

Case Report: Congestive Heart Failure  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Socioeconomic status: Middle class  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled with medications (Lisinopril 20mg daily and Metformin 500mg twice a day). He had a Myocardial Infarction (MI) four years ago  treated with angioplasty and stenting. He has been on aspirin and atorvastatin since his MI. He smoked for 30 years but stopped after his MI. There is no family history of heart disease.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Doe presents to the emergency department with an acute episode of shortness of breath which has been worsening over 5 days. He also complains of mild chest discomfort and palpitations. He reports feeling fatigued  with reduced exercise tolerance over the past few weeks. He has noticed a weight gain of approximately 10 pounds over the past month and has swelling in his legs and feet. He has been taking his medications regularly.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he appears breathless. Oxygen saturation is 90%  blood pressure is 165/90mmHg  and heart rate is 98 beats per minute. Auscultation of the lungs reveals rales at the bases  indicative of fluid buildup. Heart sounds reveal an S3 gallop. There is pitting edema in both lower extremities  up to the level of the shins.   Conclusion:  This case describes a patient presenting with symptoms and signs of heart failure  particularly left-sided heart failure. His risk factors include a history of hypertension  diabetes  a prior MI  advanced age  and a substantial history of smoking  which are commonly listed in literature as risk factors for heart failure. The case provides a chance for the students to discuss the pathophysiology  differential diagnoses  appropriate investigations  and the management approach for a patient with heart failure.

Title: Heart Failure in Elderly African American Male  Patient Information:  Mr. J is a 70-year-old African American male from an urban setting  retired steelworker  living with his wife. He has a 45 pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He maintains a sedentary lifestyle and follows a diet high in sodium and fats. He mentions drinking alcohol moderately in his younger years.   Past Medical History:  Mr. J has a significant medical history including hypertension diagnosed for the past 15 years  type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years and was treated for a myocardial infarction 5 years ago. His medications include Metoprolol  Lisinopril  and Metformin. He has been inconsistent with his medications due to financial constraints. He has no known allergies.  Presenting Complaints:  For the past few months  Mr. J has been experiencing worsening shortness of breath  initially with exertion  but now even at rest. He has also noted a persistent  unexplained weight gain  leg swelling  and complained about disturbed sleep due to frequent nocturnal urination.   The aim here is to make the medical students identify the symptoms of heart failure while taking into consideration the patient's age  racial background  socioeconomic status  and non-compliance to medication. The training case is designed to understand the pathophysiology of heart failure  its risk factors  the importance of patient education  as well as its diagnosis  management  and possible complications. Furthermore  it emphasizes addressing potential barriers to care and considerations for reducing health disparities.    Please note this case presentation is fictional and any resemblance to a real person is purely coincidental.

Case Report: Heart Failure  Patient Information:  Mr. Lopez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  retired construction worker  married  living with his wife and son in urban Los Angeles  California.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Lopez has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 15 years ago  which he manages with Metformin. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years  consuming about 10 cigarettes per day. He has a history of hypertension for about 10 years that he manages using Lisinopril. His BMI is 27 kg/m2 indicating overweight. His family history is positive for ischemic heart diseases (both parents).  Chief Complaint:  Mr. Lopez presents with gradually worsening shortness of breath over the past six months  which he initially dismissed as getting older and out of shape. He also mentions increased fatigue  particularly noticeable when trying to play soccer with his grandson. Over the last week  he has noticed swelling in his feet and ankles. The swelling seems to reduce somewhat overnight but gets worse as the day goes on. His wife also noticed that he wakes up at night gasping for breath.  The patient's self-reporting and documented hypertension  along with his symptomology suggesting fluid buildup and decreased cardiovascular capacity  points towards possible heart failure  given his risk factors of longstanding smoking  diabetes  and family history.  For accurate demographic representation  it's important to note that heart failure is common in older males  with a higher prevalence in Hispanic individuals. Smoking  obesity  uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  urban living  and a sedentary lifestyle are known risk factors. As per reported literature  these markers are more commonly found in lower socioeconomic status  which aligns with Mr. Lopez's employment history and living conditions.

Case Report:  Patient Profile:   Mr. Rodriguez  a 71-year-old Hispanic male who recently retired as a truck driver  presents to the clinic with complaints of increased fatigue  persistent cough  and difficulty catching his breath  especially at night and during minimal physical exertion. His current residence is New York  NY and he lives with his wife who has noticed significant swelling in his ankles and feet over the past month. Mr. Rodriguez is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. He has a pet dog.  Medical History:  Mr. Rodriguez has been diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago. His blood pressure and blood sugar levels are currently not well controlled  despite compliance with prescribed antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. He suffers from obesity with a body mass index (BMI) of 32. His diet is high in salt and he leads a sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activity. He also reported a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a heart attack at age 64.  Chief Complaints:  1. Fatigue and weakness - Gradual onset  progressively worsening over the past three months. 2. Difficulty in breathing - Experiencing shortness of breath especially while lying flat (orthopnea) and paroxysmal noctural dyspnea (PND) (awakening him from sleep) for the past two months. 3. Persistent dry cough - Started a month ago  worsening at night and while lying flat. 4. Swelling in legs  ankles and feet (peripheral edema) - Noticed by the wife in the past month.  This case gives an account of a person who is at high risk for developing heart failure due to multiple risk factors including age  ethnicity  hypertension  diabetes  obesity  high salt diet  sedentary lifestyle and family history of cardiovascular disease. Detailed examination  diagnostic testing  and a thoughtful treatment approach can be discussed by medical students as they work through this case.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  - Name: James Brown - Gender: Male - Age: 68 years  - Race: African American - Occupation: Retired Mathematics Teacher - Marital Status: Widowed  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of: 1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. 2. Hypertension  3. High Cholesterol levels. 4. Mild bilaterally sensorineural hearing loss. 5. History of smoking (2 packs/day for 30 years  quit 10 years ago). 6. Father died of myocardial infarction at 72  and mother of stroke at 75.  Present Complaints:  The patient complains of worsening fatigue over the last two months  especially after mild to moderate exertion. He also reports intermittent shortness of breath especially at night or when lying down (orthopnea)  which is partially relieved by sitting upright. He further reports unexplained weight gain of 10 pounds over the last month. He denies chest discomfort  but reports occasional swelling in both of his legs  especially by end of the day (bilateral lower extremity edema).  This case represents the typical demographic and risk factors for heart failure. Heart failure affects about 5.7 million people in the U.S.  with African American men having a higher prevalence. Important considerations in this scenario include his age  race  and history of hypertension  which places him at a high-risk category for heart failure. His other conditions: diabetes  high cholesterol levels  and past smoking habits increase this risk further. This case should lead the students to possible diagnosis of congestive heart failure based on his presenting complaints and medical history.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 72-year-old African American male.  Past Medical History:  He has a longstanding history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. For these conditions  he was put on losartan and metformin  respectively  which he reports taking inconsistently. He also reports a 40-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes a day  but quit 5 years ago and has a moderate alcohol intake. His family history is significant for a father who died of a heart attack at age 67 and a mother who passed away from stroke at age 78.  Chief Complaints:  The patient presented to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath of one-week duration which has now associated with orthopnea. He describes the shortness of breath as increasingly severe  especially when lying flat in bed  requiring him to sleep on multiple pillows. He reports related symptoms including a reduced ability to exercise  fatigue  and a recent 10-pound weight gain.  Financial Status:  The patient lives with his wife and is retired from his job as a school janitor. His income is fixed  consisting of Social Security and a small pension. He expresses concern about the increasing cost of medications and sometimes chooses not to refill them due to financial constraints.  Social Background:  He is a veteran and has two adult kids living in another state. He denies any illicit drug use. He is religiously Catholic and visits church weekly.  Please note: The chosen demographic for this case study is representative of some  but not all dimensions of diversity. Heart failure is more likely to affect older adults  particularly those with conditions such as hypertension and diabetes mellitus  and it has a higher incidence and poorer outcomes in African American individuals. It is essential to treat every patient as an individual  regardless of their demographic backgrounds  and provide personalized care that meets their individual needs.

Case Report:  Patient's Profile  - Identification: Ms. Sanchez - Age: 63 years old - Sex: Female - Race: Hispanic/Latino - Occupation: Is a retired school teacher living with her older daughter. - Geographic location: Urban area  Miami  Florida.  Medical History  - Hypertension (controlled with medications) - Non-Insulin dependent Diabetes Mellitus (controlled with medications) - High cholesterol (controlled with medications) - Cerebrovascular event (2 years prior  no significant sequelae) - Smoking history: More than 30 pack years but has been smoke-free for 15 years  Key Complaints:  Ms. Sanchez presents to the outpatient department with increasing episodes of shortness of breath and difficulty in sleeping. Her daughter  who accompanied her  also mentions that Ms. Sanchez seems severely fatigued over the past week. She is frequently awakened from sleep due to the feeling of suffocation and uses multiple pillows for relief (orthopnea). Recently  she also began complaining of swelling around her ankles. Furthermore  her endurance seems to have decreased  as she cannot walk two blocks without experiencing shortness of breath which was not the case earlier.  Brief Note:   The aim of this case study is to give medical students an overview of heart failure early indicators and management. It signifies the importance of a comprehensive approach considering the patient's medical history  current symptoms  demographic information  psychosocial factors  and lifestyle behaviors. Students should learn to perform a complete physical examination  relevant investigations to come up with a most probable diagnosis  and outline a personalized management plan. This also includes educating patients about lifestyle modifications and regular follow-ups. This case represents a typical heart failure patient  as the prevalence of heart failure increases with age and is more common among women and people with hypertension and diabetes. Hispanic/Latino adults are also more likely to have heart failure before age 65.

Case Report:  Patient Details: Mr. Jamal Washington  a 65-year-old African-American male  born and residing in Detroit  Michigan  USA.  Past Medical History: Mr. Washington has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes for the past 20 years managed by diet  exercise  and medication (Amlodipine 5mg once daily  Metformin 500mg twice daily). He also has a prior diagnosis of hyperlipidemia  managed with atorvastatin. There is no known family history of heart disease. However  he has been a smoker for over 25 years  and his lifestyle includes a diet high in processed food and minimal regular exercise.  Key Complaints: For the past several months  he has been experiencing progressive shortness of breath  particularly when lying flat (orthopnea). He has noticed swelling in his ankles and feet (peripheral edema) that is most pronounced in the evenings. He also has been feeling fatigued and notes an unintentional weight gain of 10 lbs over the past month.  These persistent and worsening symptoms of breathlessness  fatigue  and edema led him to present at the emergency room. In terms of vital signs  his blood pressure is elevated at 145/95  pulse 98 beats per minute and respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute.  Given the demographics  diagnosis of heart disease  and heart failure being widely prevalent among African-Americans and people aged over 65  it would be important to explore the possibility of heart failure in Mr. Washington's Case.   The educational purpose of this case is to highlight the importance of early detection and management of heart failure  especially in a subset of population who are at higher risk due to both physiological factors (age  race) and lifestyle choices (smoking  poor diet  minimal exercise).

Case Study:  Patient Demographics: Mr. Gonzalez  a 72-year-old Hispanic male  retired construction worker  living with his wife in an urban neighborhood in Texas.  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension for the last 15 years  controlled with medication (Lisinopril 20 mg once daily). He also has type 2 diabetes for 10 years  managed with Metformin (1000 mg twice daily) and a structured diet. He used to smoke a pack of cigarettes daily but quit smoking 15 years back. He doesn't have any known allergies and has no family history of heart disease.   Key complaints: Mr. Gonzalez complained of progressive shortness of breath over the past two months  even during mild exertion like walking to the mailbox. He also mentioned experiencing intermittent episodes of rapid  irregular heartbeats  severe tiredness and weakness  and unexplained weight gain with belly swelling over the last few weeks. He admits to an increasing need to urinate at night and a persistent cough or wheezing with white or pink blood-tinged phlegm.   Rationale:  According to American Heart Association (AHA)  heart failure affects a significantly higher rate in the Hispanic population. Aging  hypertension  diabetes  and past smoking history increases Mr. Gonzalez's risk of heart failure  and his current symptoms are quite suggestive of the same.   This case gives medical students a comprehensive scenario in discussing heart failure  the role of risk factors  and symptom analysis in diagnosis. It also discusses the importance of lifestyle factors  like smoking and dietary habits. The case also provides an opportunity to explore the management of comorbid conditions  population-specific disease prevalence details  and health disparities.

Case Title: Congestive Heart Failure in an Elderly African American Male  Patient Profile: Mr. J. B.  a 67-year-old African American male  is residing in Birmingham  Alabama.  Past Medical History: Mr. J.B. has a past medical history of hypertension  diagnosed 15 years ago  and type II diabetes  which was diagnosed 8 years ago. While his hypertension is usually controlled using beta blockers  his diabetes is poorly managed. Mr. J.B. previously smoked a pack a day for 35 years but quit smoking 5 years ago upon the advice of his healthcare provider  and is known to indulge moderately in alcoholic drinks.  Key Complaints: Mr. J.B. presents to the clinic reporting increased fatigue  shortness of breath (particularly on exertion)  and swelling of his lower extremities. He mentions that these symptoms have been present for a few weeks and are progressive. He further adds that for the past few days  he has found it increasingly difficult to lay flat on his bed due to breathlessness  and he has been awoken by similar episodes of shortness of breath in the past couple of nights. He also admits to unexplained weight gain over a short period.  Case Notes: Mr. J.B.’s case represents medically underserved and disproportionately affected demographic; elderly African American men have been found to have a higher risk of developing heart failure  especially in correlation with hypertension and diabetes. By introducing a patient with a background of systemic health issues  common in this demographic  the complex links between lifestyle choices  genetic factors  and social determinants of health can be emphasized. This case would also provide an opportunity for medical students to explore strategies for managing chronic health concerns  improving patient education  and improving healthcare access.  Case Learning Aims:  1. Recognize the clinical signs and symptoms of heart failure. 2. Understand the risk factors associated with heart failure  particularly highlighting the link with hypertension and diabetes. 3. Learn about diagnostic procedures and treatment options. 4. Address healthcare disparities  importance of patient education  and self-care in managing lifelong conditions.

Case Report: Heart Failure Management  Patient Demographics:  Name: Ms. Johnson Age: 62 years old Sex: Female Race/Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired School Teacher Location: Detroit  Michigan  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension - diagnosed at age 45; using antihypertensive medications (Losartan) 2. Diabetes Mellitus type 2 - diagnosed at age 52; on Metformin 3. Mild Obesity - BMI 32; struggles with weight control 4. Previous smoker - quit smoking 10 years ago 5. No known drug allergies  Chief Complaints:  Ms. Johnson has visited the clinic presenting the following symptoms which have been progressively worsening over the last 3 months:  1. Shortness of breath  especially on exertion  2. Persistent cough 3. Fatigue and weakness 4. Rapid weight gain despite no significant dietary changes 5. Noticeable swelling of lower extremities (oedema)  6. Palpitations  She expressed concern about difficulty in performing daily activities due to fatigue and breathlessness. She also complained about her shoes feeling tighter than usual  hinting at possible fluid accumulation  a condition she isn't familiar with.  Family History:   Her mother had a history of heart disease and her father had type 2 diabetes. Her elder sister died at the age of 64 due to a stroke.  Social History:  She lives alone but maintains an active social life with frequent interaction with friends  family  and community. She struggles with regular exercise due to recent increasing fatigue. She is adherent to her treatment plans for diabetes and hypertension.  At this stage  an examination is conducted with a focus on potential heart failure  to correlate with her risk factors - hypertension  diabetes  obesity  past smoker  and her current presenting symptoms. This case will help students discern the signs and steps to manage heart failure and the importance of addressing the initial complaints seriously while managing chronic illnesses.

Case Title: Chronic Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)  Patient Information: Name: Mr. Larry Rodriguez Age: 67 years old Sex: Male Race: Hispanic Occupation: Retired Construction Worker Marital Status: Married with two adult children   Patient Past Medical History: Mr. Rodriguez has obesity (BMI of 32). He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which are currently managed with lisinopril and metformin respectively. He also has a 40 pack-year smoking history  although he quit smoking 10 years ago. There is no history of surgeries or other significant diseases.   Key Presenting Complaints: Patient presents with a 2-month history of gradually worsening dyspnea on exertion  orthopnea  and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He’s been experiencing increased fatigue  especially in the latter part of the day and gaining an unintended weight of around 5kg over the past month. He also has occasional nocturia and generalized swelling in his legs  particularly noticeable in the evening.  Reason for consultation: Mr. Rodriguez’s general practitioner recommended him to see a cardiologist after an examination revealed jugular venous distension and bilateral lower extremity edema. Mr. Rodriguez is concerned about these new symptoms disrupting his daily life  specifically his ability to enjoy retirement and spend quality time with his grandchildren.   Note: The case reflects the demographic patterns observed in the literature  where heart failure prevalence increases with age and is higher in men than in women. It also takes into account the fact that heart failure is more common among individuals with a history of hypertension  diabetes  and smoking—risk factors that are disproportionately prevalent among individuals of low socioeconomic status.  Final Comment: This case can be used to teach students about the clinical presentation of CHF  its associated risk factors  and the importance of effective communication and assessment skills when interacting with patients with chronic conditions. Students should understand that heart failure is not a discrete disease  but rather the final common pathway of several cardiovascular diseases. Preventive measures are key in mitigating the disease's progression and improving patients' quality of life.   References: 1. Benjamin EJ  Muntner P  Alonso A  et al. Heart Disease and Stroke Statistics—2019 Update: A Report From the American Heart Association. Circulation. 2019;139(10):e56-e528.  2. Virani SS  Alonso A  Benjamin EJ  et al. Heart Disease and Stroke Statistics—2020 Update: A Report From the American Heart Association. Circulation. 2020;141(9):e139-e596.

Patient Case Report:   Demographics: Mr. James Sanchez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  retired construction contractor with a high school education  lives in rural New Mexico with his wife of 40 years. He has a history of smoking a pack a day for 20 years  but quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use.   Past medical history: Mr. Sanchez has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus which is poorly controlled  hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril  and hyperlipidemia managed with Simvastatin. He has no known allergies.  Key Complaints: Mr. Sanchez presented to his primary care physician with complaints of increasing shortness of breath  especially with minimal exertion like walking from his living room to the kitchen. He stated he avoids lying flat to sleep due to difficulty in breathing and wakes up breathless at night  needing to catch his breath by sitting on the side of the bed. He also reports a recent weight gain  fatigue throughout the day  and mild swelling in his ankles for the last month.  The above report is meant to serve as a concise study case to initiate further explorations into a suspected diagnosis of heart failure. The demographic details are representative of an often-observed population in heart failure literature  bringing in issues related to age  ethnicity  environment  and lifestyle habits.  *Remember Medicine is always evolving and the cases can change according to the latest literature and guidelines. Our primary focus must always remain patient-centered care.

Case Scenario: Heart Failure  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. William Taylor Age: 65 years Gender: Male Race: African American Socioeconomic status: Middle-class Insurance: Medicare Occupation: Retired School Teacher Location: Urban  Midwest  Past Medical History: Mr. Taylor has a documented history of hypertension for which he has been on medication (Lisinopril) for the past 20 years. He has been noncompliant with his medication regimen for some months due to financial constraints and reduced visits to his GP due to pandemic-related reasons. Additionally  he has Type 2 diabetes controlled by Metformin  diagnosed 10 years ago. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history but quit smoking two decades ago. His family history indicates a genetic predisposition to heart diseases; both his father and grandfather died from heart-related conditions. He is moderately overweight with a BMI of 28.  Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Taylor presents in the emergency department with chief complaints of increasing shortness of breath over the past two weeks  especially when lying flat  forcing him to sleep upright on his recliner. He also reports sporadic chest discomfort during this period  persistent cough often producing frothy sputum  lower extremity edema  and rapid weight gain in the last month. Smaller meals make him feel full  and he has a diminished appetite. He has also noticed increasing fatigue and weakness when performing regular daily living activities.  In this case scenario  the race and age parameters reflect the prevalence of heart failure being higher among African American males and individuals above 60 years. The socioeconomic status and relevant comorbidities are representative of several American patients suffering from heart failure  giving the medical students a realistic example to apply theoretical knowledge in practice. The case also highlights the importance of patient medication adherence which is vital in managing diseases such as hypertension and diabetes  which are significant risk factors for heart failure.

Patient Case: Mr. Rodriguez  Patient Demographics: The patient is Mr. Rodriguez  a 68-year-old Hispanic male who works as a retired schoolteacher. He lives with his wife and remains socially active in his community in the inner city. Mr. Rodriguez is fluent in both Spanish and English and prefers a balanced conversation of both languages. He is an ex-smoker and quit 8 years ago  but has a cumulative smoking history of 30 pack-years.  Past Medical History: Mr. Rodriguez has a known history of hypertension  diagnosed 10 years ago  and type II diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 8 years ago. He has been reasonably compliant with his medications that include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Amlodipine. He has no known allergies. His family history is significant for heart disease  with his mother dying of heart failure at the age of 75.  Key Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez presents to the primary care clinic expressing multiple complaints including increasing shortness of breath for the past 3 weeks  which has worsened significantly on mild exertion over the past week. He also mentions the feeling of fatigue and mentions that he has awakened from sleep several times as he felt 'out of breath'. He has been experiencing some swelling in his ankles  which seems to worsen by the end of the day. He mentions a weight gain of about 5 lbs in the last month.  In terms of social factors  Mr. Rodriguez cites increased stress due to financial troubles and has difficulty paying for his medications  often needing to choose between groceries and healthcare. His wife helps him manage his illnesses at home as much as possible.  The objective of this training case is to emphasize the importance of providing patient-centered care that respects and responds to individual patient preferences  needs  and values in the management of heart failure patients  as well as to highlight the socioeconomic factors that perpetuate health disparities in minority communities like Hispanics. Additionally  the case will promote the development of critical thinking and decision-making skills in managing complex patient presentations associated with heart failure.

Case Report:  **Patient Information:**  Gender: Male  Age: 88 years  Race/Ethnicity: African American  Occupation: Retired  Residential Area: Urban  **Past Medical History:**  1. Hypertension  on treatment for the past 28 years. 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus  managed with daily oral medication. 3. Previous episode of stroke with no permanent neurological complication four years ago. 4. History of smoking and alcohol consumption  quit ten years ago. 5. Family history of cardiac diseases.  **Present Complaints:**  The patient presented with a three-week history of:  1. Increasing shortness of breath  especially with minimal physical exertion (exertional dyspnea). 2. Orthopnea: breathlessness on lying flat  using three pillows to sleep at night. 3. Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea: waking up at night feeling breathless. 4. Reduced exercise tolerance: unable to walk more than 20 yards without resting. 5. Recent unexplained weight gain. 6. Distended abdomen with discomfort. 7. Swelling in both ankles.  **Note:**  This case study reflects literature data indicating that elderly African American males have a higher prevalence of heart failure. Risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  past history of stroke  and unhealthy lifestyle factors (smoking and alcohol) are included. The complaints are typical symptoms of heart failure. They are designed to guide students in understanding the clinical manifestation of heart failure.

Patient Introduction: Ms. Joanna Smith  a South Asian woman  aged 65  originally from Guyana  presently resides in Queens  New York. She is a retired teacher living with her husband and has two adult children who live out of state. She has been an active member of her local neighborhood and a part-time volunteer at a community center for the past 10 years.  Past Medical History: Ms. Smith has a history of Type 2 Diabetes (DM2) for the past 15 years  which is currently under control with medication. She has hypertension (HTN) treated with ACE inhibitors  and dyslipidemia managed with statins. She is also mildly obese  with a BMI of 31.  Current Complaint: The patient made an appointment after noticing progressive symptoms that have lasted for a month  including unusual shortness of breath when walking her regular routes or performing light chores around the house. She also complains of frequent nocturnal coughing bouts  sometimes awakening her from sleep  along with slight swelling in her ankles by the end of the day. She has also noticed a decrease in her appetite and a 10-pound weight gain over the last six weeks which she finds concerning. On questioning  she also admits to increasing fatigue and weakness in her limbs.  Initial Thoughts & Further Exploration: Given the patient's age  race  past medical history  and specific symptoms  the preliminary diagnosis leaning towards heart failure. Although coronary artery disease is also a concern  the persistence of her symptoms  DM2  and hypertension all contribute to heart failure risk. However  further investigation  medical examinations and revisions of medicine protocol should be enforced to confirm the diagnosis.  This case is designed to engage students in differential diagnosis techniques  with conditions like heart failure that presents with atypical symptoms  especially in the elderly and amongst various ethnicities. This case also will emphasize the importance of considering demographic factors and comorbidities when evaluating a patient. Students will learn to formulate an appropriate management plan and discuss potential interventions  strategies for patient education  and necessary lifestyle modifications.

Case Study: Congestive Heart Failure  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old African American male named Mr. Jackson. He is retired  previously working as a high school teacher. Mr. Jackson lives with his wife in a suburban area and has 3 adult children. He has an active lifestyle  enjoys gardening as a hobby  and recently has quit smoking a year ago after a habit of 30 years.  Past Medical History: Mr. Jackson has a significant medical history which includes high blood pressure  Type II diabetes mellitus  and high cholesterol. The diseases have been fairly managed for the past decade after being diagnosed with all three in close succession. He has been compliant with his medication regimen  which includes metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. Mr. Jackson also began a more regulated diet and exercise program after his diagnoses to manage his health more actively. His family history is significant with his father dying of congestive heart failure at an age of 70.  Key Complaints: Mr. Jackson visits his primary care physician complaining of symptoms that have deteriorated over the past three weeks. His symptoms consist of increased fatigue  breathlessness especially when lying flat (orthopnea)  and edema in his ankles. He also mentions that he has been experiencing difficulty in carrying out the same level of physical activity as before. He complains of waking up gasping for air in the middle of night  and having to sleep propped up by pillows (paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea). He has also noted an increase in his weight over the past few days.  Considerations: This case is designed to reflect the significant incidence and prevalence of heart failure in the African American population  with hypertension being a strong risk factor. New York Heart Association (NYHA) classification of symptoms could be an important part of discussion as well as understanding the pathophysiology of heart failure symptoms. Ultimately  this case will encompass proper symptom assessment  diagnosis  and management of congestive heart failure. It can touch upon the importance of lifestyle modifications in heart failure management and the role of patient self-care.

CASE REPORT:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 60-year-old African American male  unemployed  who lives in an urban neighborhood in Philadelphia. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day and reports occasional alcohol use.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known past medical history of Type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He is currently on metformin  amlodipine  and atorvastatin. He has not had any surgeries in the past. The patient's adherence to medications and regular follow-up is inconsistent due to financial issues and mental health challenges  including occasional bouts of depression. His family history reveals that his father had coronary artery disease and died from a heart attack at the age of 65. The patient is divorced and lives alone; he has two adult children who live out of state.  Chief Complaint: The patient came to the hospital complaining of shortness of breath  particularly when lying flat. He reports that these episodes have been becoming more frequent and severe over the past few months. There is an associated cough which produces frothy sputum. He has noticed an increase in the swelling of his legs and has gained weight over the past few weeks. He is also experiencing fatigue  palpitations  and decreased urine output. The patient denies any chest pain  nausea  or vomiting.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appears slightly distressed. His blood pressure is 170/90 mmHg  Pulse 98/min  Respiratory Rate 22/min  Temperature 98.6 F  and Oxygen saturation 90% on room air. The cardiopulmonary exam reveals an elevated jugular venous pressure  the presence of S3  and lower limb edema. Breath sounds are decreased at lung bases with crackles heard bilaterally. Rest of the examination is unremarkable.   This case should facilitate a discussion about heart failure  risk factors (hypertension  African American race  male gender  smoking  diabetes  noncompliance to medication)  signs and symptoms  and the underlying pathophysiology. It can also initiate a conversation about health disparities and the social determinants of health.

Case: Patient Information: Mrs. Maria Gonzales  a 64-year-old Hispanic female  residing in an urban area.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Gonzales has a 10-year history of high blood pressure managed with medication (lisinopril). She does not smoke or consume alcohol regularly. Her father died of a heart attack at 72 and her mother  alive at 90  suffers from type 2 diabetes. She has worked in administrative roles for most of her life and her activity level is modest. Maria also suffers from obesity (BMI: 30.7)  and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 3 years ago  managed with Metformin.   Presenting Complaint: Over the past couple of months  Dr. Gonzales has noticed increasing shortness of breath  particularly during her regular morning walks. More recently  she has experienced oedema in her lower limbs and some associated weight gain. She's also mentioned feeling lightheaded and fatigued easily. She's particularly worried as she's been waking up breathless in the night.   This case thus presents a classic heart failure scenario. With known risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  advancing age  history of family heart disease and obesity  the patient's symptoms align well with a likely differential diagnosis of heart failure. Students can be directed to consider what additional testing might help confirm the diagnosis  differential diagnoses  the potential underlying mechanism(s)  and possible treatment strategies to manage Mrs. Gonzales's condition better.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 65 years - Gender: Male - Race: African American - Occupation: Retired Postal Worker - Address: Urban area  Past Medical History: - Smoker for 30 years  quit 5 years ago - Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  poorly controlled - Non-insulin dependent Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 7 years ago - Obese with a body mass index of 33 - Hyperlipidemia - One episode of chronic kidney disease (CKD) 2 years ago - No known allergies  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe came to the general outpatient clinic with the chief complaint of increasing shortness of breath  particularly when lying flat  and a persistent cough over the last three months. He also reports sever fatigue that makes it difficult to perform ordinary activities  noticeable weight gain with swelling in the feet  ankles  legs  and occasionally  the abdomen  loss of appetite  high heart rate  and feelings of confusion or inability to think clearly.  Note: African Americans are disproportionately affected by heart failure  with higher rates at a younger age in comparison to other races. Issues such as hypertension  obesity  diabetes  and lifestyle factors (such as smoking) are directly linked to the increased risk and earlier onset of heart failure. This case has been designed to demonstrate the interplay between these factors in the disease state. The symptoms presented are consistent with congestive heart failure and represent a typical  to-be-expected late stage patient presentation.
